title:
Identification by non-Gaussianity in structural threshold and smooth
  transition vector autoregressive models

sections.text:
#### Abstract

Linear structural vector autoregressive models can be identified statistically without imposing restrictions on the model if the shocks are mutually independent and at most one of them is Gaussian. We show that this result extends to structural threshold and smooth transition vector autoregressive models incorporating a time-varying impact matrix defined as a weighted sum of the impact matrices of the regimes. We also discuss the problem of labelling the shocks, estimation of the parameters, and stationarity the model. The introduced methods are implemented to the accompanying R package sstvars. Our empirical application studies the effects of the climate policy uncertainty shock on the U.S. macroeconomy. In a structural logistic smooth transition vector autoregressive model with two regimes, we find that a positive climate policy uncertainty shock decreases production and increases inflation in times of both low and high economic policy uncertainty, but its inflationary effects are stronger in the periods of high economic policy uncertainty.


Keywords: smooth transition vector autoregression, threshold VAR, nonlinear SVAR, identification by non-Gaussianity, non-Gaussian SVAR

# 1 Introduction 

Linear vector autoregressive (VAR) models are a standard tool in empirical macroeconomics due to their ability to effectively capture constant dynamic relationships of the included variables. Macroeconomic systems may, however, exhibit variation in their dynamics, induced by wars, crises, policy shifts, or business cycle fluctuations, for example. Such structural changes cannot be accommodated by linear VAR models, and therefore, nonlinear VAR models that are able capture such dynamics are often employed. Nonlinear structural VAR (SVAR) models are particularly useful, as they facilitate tracing out the causal effects of economic shocks, which may vary in time depending on the initial state of the economy as well as on the sign and size of the shock (Kilian and Lütkepohl, 2017, Chapter 18). To estimate these effects, the economic shocks need to be identified. Conventional identification methods typically employed in nonlinear SVAR models rely on restrictive assumptions, such as zero contemporaneous interactions among some of the variables (see Kilian and Lütkepohl, 2017, Section 18.2.2). Such restrictions with a clear interpretation are advantageous when based on economic reasoning, but often they are economically implausible and imposed just to achieve sufficient identification. To overcome the latter issue, statistical identification methods relying on the statistical properties of the data can be used.

There are two main branches in the statistical identification literature: identification by heteroscedasticity (Rigobon, 2003, Lanne, Lütkepohl, and Maciejowska, 2010, Bacchiocchi and Fanelli, 2015, Lütkepohl and Netšunajev, 2017, Lewis, 2021, Virolainen, 2025b, and others) and identification by non-Gaussianity (Lanne, Meitz, and Saikkonen, 2017, Lanne and Luoto, 2021, Lanne, Liu, and Luoto, 2023, and others). To the best our knowledge, this paper is the first to study identification by non-Gaussianity in nonlinear SVAR models. Under certain statistical conditions, both types of identification methods typically identify the shocks of a linear structural vector autoregressive (SVAR) model without imposing further restrictions. However, identification by heteroscedasticity without additional restrictions (as described in the cited literature) has the major drawback in nonlinear SVAR models that, for each shock, it restricts the relative magnitudes of the impact re-

sponses of the variables to stay constant over time (see, e.g., Lütkepohl and Netšunajev, 2017). This is an undesirable property because it is generally preferable to accommodate time-variation in the (relative) impact responses.

This paper contributes to the literature on identification by non-Gaussianity by extending the framework proposed by Lanne et al. (2017) to smooth transition vector autoregressive (STVAR) models (e.g., Anderson and Vahid, 1998), which is major class of nonlinear SVAR models. We also consider the threshold vector autoregressive model of Tsay (1998) as a special case of the STVAR model. The STVAR model can flexibly capture nonlinear data generating dynamics by accommodating multiple regimes and gradual shifts between them, governed by the transition weighs. In contrast to its linear counterpart, the impact matrix of the structural STVAR model should generally allow for time-variation in the impact responses of the variables to the shocks, which complicates identification. Nonetheless, similarly to Lanne et al. (2017), it turns out that identification is achieved when the shocks are mutually independent and at most one of them is Gaussian. We show that under this condition, when the impact matrix of the STVAR model is defined as a weighted sum of the impact matrices of the regimes, the shocks are readily identified up to ordering and signs. The weights of the impact matrices are the transition weights of the regimes, which we assume to be either exogenous, logistic, or of the threshold form, but our results can be extended to other suitable weight functions as well.

In line with the statistical identification literature, external information is required to label the identified structural shocks as economic shocks. Our nonlinear setup has the additional complication that the same shock should be assigned to the same column of the impact matrix across all regimes. Therefore, since our experience shows that the identification can be weak with respect to the ordering and signs of the columns of the regime-specific impact matrices, we recommend adopting a blended identification strategy that combines identification by non-Gaussianity with additional identifying information (cf. Carriero, Marcellino, and Tornese, 2024).

Developments related to ours include the new framework of Morioka, Hälvä, and Hyvärinen (2021)

called independent innovation analysis (IIA). The IIA estimates the (conditionally) contemporaneously independent innovations of a nonlinear SVAR model without imposing any specific functional form. Under fairly general assumptions, their method consistently estimates the independent innovations up to permutation and scalar component-wise invertible transformations. While the IIA does seem promising, it is not obvious how to apply it in empirical macroeconometrics, as identification only up to such transformations is, in our understanding, insufficient for structural analysis. Moreover, Morioka et al. (2021) assume the innovations follow a distribution in the exponential family, thereby excluding various interesting alternatives. In contrast, our approach facilitates estimation of the parameters of an identified nonlinear SVAR model, enabling structural analysis without restricting the distribution of independent shocks beyond ruling out Gaussian and infinite-variance cases.

Our empirical application studies the macroeconomic effects of climate policy uncertainty (shocks) and considers monthly U.S. data from 1987:4 to 2024:12. Following Khalil and Strobel (2023) and Huang and Punzi (2024), we measure climate policy uncertainty (CPU) with the CPU index (Gavriilidis, 2021), which is constructed based on the amount of newspaper coverage on topics related to CPU. We are interested in studying how the effects of the CPU shock vary depending on the level of economic policy uncertainty (EPU). Therefore, we fit a two-regime structural logistic STVAR model using the first lag of the EPU index (Baker, Bloom, and Davis, 2016) as the switching variable. We find that a positive CPU shock decreases production and increases inflation in times of both low and high EPU, but its inflationary effects are stronger in the periods of high EPU. Our results are, hence, in line with the previous literature suggesting that a positive CPU shock decreases production (Fried, Novan, and Peterman, 2022, Khalil and Strobel, 2023, and Huang and Punzi, 2024) and increases inflation (Khalil and Strobel, 2023, and Huang and Punzi, 2024).

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. Section 2 presents the framework of reduced form STVAR models and provides examples of the covered models. Section 3 discusses identification of the shocks in structural STVAR models, presents our results on identification by non-Gaussianity,

and discusses the problem of labelling the shocks. Section 4 discusses stationarity of the model and proposes estimating its parameters with a penalized likelihood -based estimator using a threestep procedure. Section 5 presents the empirical application and Section 6 concludes. Appendices provide detailed discussion on ergodic stationarity of the model; proofs for the stated lemmas, propositions, and theorem; details related to the proposed estimation procedure; a Monte Carlo study assessing the performance of the proposed estimator; and details related to the empirical application. Finally, the introduced methods have been implemented to the accompanying R package sstvars (Virolainen, 2025a), which is available via the CRAN repository.

## 2 Reduced form STVAR models

Let $y_{t}, t=1,2, \ldots$, be the $d$-dimensional time series of interest and $\mathcal{F}_{t-1}$ denote the $\sigma$-algebra generated by the random vectors $\left\{y_{t-j}, j>0\right\}$. We consider STVAR models with $M$ regimes and autoregressive order $p$ assumed to satisfy

$$
\begin{aligned}
y_{t} & =\sum_{m=1}^{M} \alpha_{m, t} \mu_{m, t}+u_{t}, \quad u_{t} \sim M D\left(0, \Omega_{y, t}, \nu\right) \\
\mu_{m, t} & =\phi_{m}+\sum_{i=1}^{p} A_{m, i} y_{t-i}, \quad m=1, \ldots, M
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\phi_{1}, \ldots, \phi_{M} \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ are the intercept parameters; $A_{1, i}, \ldots, A_{M, i} \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times d}, i=1, \ldots, p$, are the autoregression matrices; $u_{t}$ is a martingale difference sequence of reduced form innovations; $\Omega_{y, t}$ is the positive definite conditional covariance matrix of $u_{t}$ (conditional on $\mathcal{F}_{t-1}$ ), which may depend on $\alpha_{1, t}, \ldots, \alpha_{M, t}$ and $y_{t-1}, \ldots, y_{t-p}$; and $\nu$ collects any other parameters that the distribution of $u_{t}$ depends on. The transition weights $\alpha_{m, t}$ are assumed to be either exogenous (nonrandom) or $\mathcal{F}_{t-1^{-}}$ measurable functions of $\left\{y_{t-j}, j=1, \ldots, p\right\}$, and to satisfy $\sum_{m=1}^{M} \alpha_{m, t}=1$ at all $t$. Thus, the types of transition weights typically used in macroeconomic applications, including exogenous, logistic, and threshold weights discussed below, are accommodated. The transition weights express the

proportions of the regimes the process is on at each point of time and determine how the process shifts between them.

It is easy to see that, conditional on $\mathcal{F}_{t-1}$, the conditional mean of the above-described process is $\mu_{y, t} \equiv E\left[y_{t} \mid \mathcal{F}_{t-1}\right]=\sum_{m=1}^{M} \alpha_{m, t} \mu_{m, t}$, a weighted sum the regime-specific means $\mu_{m, t}$ with the weights given by the transition weights $\alpha_{m, t}$. The conditional covariance matrix is $\Omega_{y, t}$, but discussion on its specification is postponed to Section 3. See Hubrich and Teräsvirta (2013) for a survey on STVAR literature, including also specifications more general than ours.

Our framework accommodates various types of transition weights employed in empirical macroeconomics. To provide a few examples, consider first the threshold VAR (TVAR) model (Tsay, 1998), which is obtained from (2.1) and (2.2) by assuming that the transition weights are defined as

$$
\alpha_{m, t}= \begin{cases}1 & \text { if } r_{m-1}<z_{t} \leq r_{m} \\ 0 & \text { otherwise }\end{cases}
$$

where $r_{0} \equiv-\infty, r_{M} \equiv \infty, m=1, \ldots, M$, are threshold parameters, and $z_{t}$ is a switching variable. At each $t$, the model defined in Equations (2.1), (2.2) and (2.3) reduces to a linear VAR corresponding to one of the regimes that is determined according to the level of the switching variable $z_{t}$, which can be an exogenous variable, a lagged endogenous variable, or a linear combination of multiple such variables, for example.

Another popular specification is to assume two regimes $(M=2)$ and logistic transition weights. In the logistic STVAR model (Anderson and Vahid, 1998), the transition weights vary according to a logistic function as

$$
\alpha_{1, t}=1-\alpha_{2, t} \text { and } \alpha_{2, t}=\left[1+\exp \left\{-\gamma\left(z_{t}-c\right)\right\}\right]^{-1}
$$

where $z_{t}$ is the switching variable, $c \in \mathbb{R}$ is a location parameter, and $\gamma>0$ is a scale parameter. The location parameter $c$ determines the midpoint of the transition function, i.e., the value of the switching variable when the weights are equal. The scale parameter $\gamma$, in turn, determines the

smoothness of the transitions (smaller $\gamma$ implies smoother transitions), and it is assumed strictly positive so that $\alpha_{2, t}$ is increasing in $z_{t}$.

In addition to specifying the transition weights or the error process $u_{t}$ in various ways, different types of models can be obtained by imposing parameter restrictions to the model defined in (2.1)(2.2). For instance, a model that is linear in the autoregressive (AR) coefficients is obtained by assuming that they are constant across the regimes, i.e., $A_{m, i}=A_{i}$ and $\phi_{m}=\phi$ for all $i=1, \ldots, p$ and $M=1, \ldots, M$. The model then simplifies to

$$
y_{t}=\phi+\sum_{i=1}^{p} A_{i} y_{t-i}+u_{t}, \quad u_{t} \sim M D\left(0, \Omega_{y, t}, \nu\right)
$$

The linear model in (2.5) is typically substantially easier to estimate and has much fewer parameters than the fully nonlinear specification in (2.1)-(2.2), making it more feasible for large scale SVAR analyses, but it can still accommodate shifts in the volatility regime through the error process $u_{t}$.

# 3 Structural STVAR models identified by non-Gaussianity
### 3.1 Structural STVAR models

A structural STVAR model is obtained from the reduced form model defined in Section 2 by identifying the serially and mutually uncorrelated structural shocks $e_{t}=\left(e_{1 t}, \ldots, e_{d t}\right)(d \times 1)$ from the reduced form innovations $u_{t}$. Specifically, the structural shocks are recovered from the reduced form shocks with the transformation

$$
e_{t}=B_{y, t}^{-1} u_{t}
$$

where $B_{y, t}$ is an invertible $(d \times d)$ impact matrix that governs the contemporaneous relationships of the shocks and may depend on $\alpha_{1, t}, \ldots, \alpha_{M, t}$ and $y_{t-1}, \ldots, y_{t-p}$. In other words, assuming a unit

variance normalization for the structural shocks, the identification problem amounts to finding an impact matrix $B_{y, t}$ such that $\Omega_{y, t}=B_{y, t} B_{y, t}^{\prime}$. The impact matrix is not, however, generally uniquely identified without imposing further restrictions on the model, since there exists many such decompositions of $\Omega_{y, t}$. Various types of restrictions that recover the structural shocks have been proposed in the literature, many of which are discussed in Kilian and Lütkepohl (2017), for example.

Following the literature on statistical identification by non-Gaussianity in the framework proposed by Lanne et al. (2017), our identifying restriction is that the shocks are mutually independent and at most one of them is Gaussian. Under this assumption, unlike in the Gaussian case, different decompositions of the conditional covariance matrix $\Omega_{y, t}=B_{y, t} B_{y, t}^{\prime}$ generally lead to observationally distinct models, effectively identifying a static impact matrix and the shocks (Lanne et al., 2017). We extend this result to a time-varying impact matrix, and therefore, it is useful to parametrize the structural model directly with $B_{y, t}$. Hence, we make the identity $u_{t}=B_{y, t} e_{t}$ explicit in Equation (2.1) as

$$
y_{t}=\sum_{m=1}^{M} \alpha_{m, t}\left(\phi_{m}+\sum_{i=1}^{p} A_{m, i} y_{t-i}\right)+B_{y, t} e_{t}, \quad e_{t} \sim I I D\left(0, I_{d}, \nu\right)
$$

where $e_{t}$ are independent and identically distributed structural errors with identity covariance matrix and a distribution that may depend on the parameter $\nu$.

To incorporate time-variation in the impact matrix, we specify its functional form. A natural specification for STVAR models is to assume a constant impact matrix for each of the regimes and define the impact matrix of the process to be their weighted sum as

$$
B_{y, t}=\sum_{m=1}^{M} \alpha_{m, t} B_{m}
$$

where $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}$ are invertible $(d \times d)$ impact matrices of the regimes. Also the impact matrix $B_{y, t}$ needs to be invertible to ensure positive definiteness of the conditional covariance matrix, which

does not automatically follow from the invertibility of $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}$. Nevertheless, it turns out that $B_{y, t}$ defined in (3.3) is invertible for all $t$ almost everywhere in $\left[B_{1}: \ldots: B_{M}\right] \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times d M}$, as is stated in the following lemma (which is proven in Appendix B.1).

Lemma 1. Suppose $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}$ are invertible $(d \times d)$ matrices and $\alpha_{1, t}, \ldots, \alpha_{M, t}$ scalars such that $\sum_{m=1}^{M} \alpha_{m, t}=1$ and $\alpha_{m, t} \geq 0$ for all $t$ and $m=1, \ldots, M$. Then, the matrix $B_{y, t}=\sum_{m=1}^{M} \alpha_{m, t} B_{m}$ is invertible for all $t$ almost everywhere in $\left[B_{1}: \ldots: B_{M}\right] \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times d M}$.

The result of Lemma 1 holds almost everywhere in $\left[B_{1}: \ldots: B_{M}\right] \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times d M}$, which means that the set where the matrices $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}$ are such that $B_{y, t}$ is singular for some $t$ has a Lebesgue measure zero. This implies that invertible matrices $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}$ generally lead to an invertible impact matrix $B_{y, t}$, excluding some special cases of $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}$ for which this result does not hold (e.g., if $B_{2}=-B_{1}$, then $B_{y, t}=0$ when $\alpha_{1, t}=\alpha_{2, t}=0.5$ ). To further improve intuition, note that the result of Lemma 1 implies that if the matrices $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}$ are drawn by random from a continuous distribution, the probability of obtaining matrices such that $B_{y, t}$ is singular for some $t$ is zero. In practice, the parameter space should be simply restricted in estimation so that parameter values leading to $B_{y, t}$ that is singular for some $t$ are excluded.

Assuming impact matrix of the form (3.3), the conditional covariance matrix of $y_{t}$, conditional on $\mathcal{F}_{t-1}$, is obtained as

$$
\Omega_{y, t}=\left(\sum_{m=1}^{M} \alpha_{m, t} B_{m}\right)\left(\sum_{m=1}^{M} \alpha_{m, t} B_{m}\right)^{\prime}=\sum_{m=1}^{M} \alpha_{m, t}^{2} \Omega_{m}+\sum_{m=1}^{M} \sum_{n=1, n \neq m}^{M} \alpha_{m, t} \alpha_{n, t} \Omega_{m, n}
$$

where $\Omega_{m} \equiv B_{m} B_{m}^{\prime}$ and $\Omega_{m, n} \equiv B_{m} B_{n}^{\prime}$. The conditional covariance matrix of $y_{t}$ can be thus described as a weighted sum of $M^{2}$ matrices with the weights varying in time according to the transition weights $\alpha_{m, t}, m=1, \ldots, M$. If the process is completely in one of the regimes, i.e., $\alpha_{m, t}=1$ for some $m \in\{1, \ldots, M\}$, then $\Omega_{y, t}$ reduces to $\Omega_{m}$, implying that this constitutes as the conditional covariance matrix of Regime $m$. When the process is not completely in any of the regimes, $\Omega_{y, t}$ depends on both the regime-specific covariance matrices and the cross terms.

Hence, this specification of the structural model is different to the conventional reduced form STVAR specification in which the conditional covariance matrix of $y_{t}$ is a weighted sum of the covariance matrices of the regimes. Nonetheless, our model specification facilitates exploiting non-Gaussianity of the shocks in their identification, as we show in the next section.

# 3.2 Identification of the shocks by non-Gaussianity 

The key identification assumption is that the structural shocks $e_{t}=\left(e_{1 t}, \ldots, e_{d t}\right)$ are mutually independent and at most one of them is Gaussian. We also assume that $e_{t}$ is an IID sequence with zero mean and identity covariance matrix as is formally stated in the following assumption.

Assumption 1. (i) The structural error process $e_{t}=\left(e_{1 t}, \ldots, e_{d t}\right)$ is a sequence of independent and identically distributed random vectors such that $e_{t}$ is independent of $\mathcal{F}_{t-1}$ and each component $e_{i t}, i=1, \ldots, d$, follows a continuous distribution with zero mean and unit variance.
(ii) The components of $e_{t}=\left(e_{1 t}, \ldots, e_{d t}\right)$ are mutually independent and at most one them has a Gaussian marginal distribution.

Note that the assumption of a unit variance is merely a normalization since the variance of the shocks is captured by the impact matrix $B_{y, t}$. Also, due to the time-variation of the impact matrix (3.3), Assumption 1 does not imply that the reduced form innovations $u_{t}$ are independent nor that they are identically distributed.

The next lemma then shows that at each $t$, conditionally on $\mathcal{F}_{t-1}$, the impact matrix $B_{y, t}$ is uniquely identified up to ordering and signs of its columns. This lemma, which is partly similar to Proposition 1 in Lanne et al. (2017), is used in the following sections to show that the impact matrices $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}$ of the regimes in (3.3) are identified. Moreover, Lemma 2 also shows that if the transition weights are either exogenous and nonrandom, or they follow the threshold (2.3) or the logistic (2.4) process, then also the autoregressive (AR) and weight function parameters are identified.

Specific weight functions are assumed here for simplicity, but the result can be extended to other suitable weight functions as well.

Lemma 2. Consider the STVAR model defined in Equations (3.2) and (3.3) with Assumption 1 satisfied. Then, conditionally on $\mathcal{F}_{t-1}$, at each $t, B_{y, t}$ is uniquely identified up to ordering and signs of its columns almost everywhere in $\left[B_{1}: \ldots: B_{M}\right] \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times d M}$.

Moreover, suppose the observed time series is $y_{-p+1}, \ldots, y_{0}, y_{1}, \ldots, y_{T}$ and that the following conditions hold:
(1) the transition weights $\alpha_{m, t}, m=1, \ldots, M$, are either exogenous (nonrandom), or they follow the threshold (2.3) or the logistic process (2.4) (with $M=2$ in the latter),
(2) $\left(\phi_{m}, \operatorname{vec}\left(A_{m, 1}\right), \ldots, \operatorname{vec}\left(A_{m, p}\right)\right) \neq\left(\phi_{n}, \operatorname{vec}\left(A_{n, 1}\right), \ldots, \operatorname{vec}\left(A_{n, p}\right)\right)$ for all $m \neq n \in\{1, \ldots, M\}$, and
(3) there exists $M$ indices $t_{1}, \ldots, t_{M} \in\{1, \ldots, T\}$ such that the corresponding coefficient vectors $\left(\alpha_{1, t_{i}}, \ldots, \alpha_{M, t_{i}}\right), i=1, \ldots, M$, are linearly independent.

Then, for models with exogenous weights, the parameters $\phi_{m}, A_{m, 1}, \ldots A_{m, p}, m=1, \ldots, M$ are uniquely identified almost everywhere in $\left(y_{-p+1}, \ldots, y_{0}, y_{1}, \ldots, y_{T-1}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{d(T+p-1)}$. For threshold models (2.3), the parameters $\phi_{m}, A_{m, 1}, \ldots A_{m, p}, m=1, \ldots, M$ and $r_{1}, \ldots, r_{m-1}$ are uniquely identified almost everywhere in $\left(y_{-p+1}, \ldots, y_{0}, y_{1}, \ldots, y_{T-1}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{d(T+p-1)}$. For logistic models (2.4), the parameters $\phi_{m}, A_{m, 1}, \ldots A_{m, p}, m=1,2$, and $c, \gamma$ are uniquely identified almost everywhere in $\left(y_{-p+1}, \ldots, y_{0}, y_{1}, \ldots, y_{T-1}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{d(T+p-1)}$ and, if the switching variable $z_{t}$ defined in Section 2 is exogenous, $\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{T}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{T}$.

Lemma 2 is proven in Appendix B.2.

We have concluded that at each $t$, conditionally on $\mathcal{F}_{t-1}$, the impact matrix $B_{y, t}$ is unique up to ordering and signs of its columns under Assumption 1. In other words, at each $t$, changing the

ordering or signs of the columns of $B_{y, t}$ would lead to an observationally equivalent model, but changing $B_{y, t}$ in any other way would lead to an observationally distinct model. The result holds only almost everywhere in $\left[B_{1}: \ldots: B_{M}\right] \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times d M}$, because $B_{y, t}$ is invertible almost everywhere by Lemma 1. Identification of the AR and weight function parameters, in turn, is achieved only almost everywhere in $\left(y_{-p+1}, \ldots, y_{0}, y_{1}, \ldots, y_{T-1}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{d(T+p-1)}$ (and $\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{T}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{T}$ ), because the identification fails in some special cases that comprise a set with Lebesgue measure zero. Condition (3) of Lemma 2 ensures that the transition weights exhibit enough variation to distinguish between different parameter values. If there are only two regimes, this condition is satisfied if transition weights take at least two distinct values.

If the impact matrix is time-invariant as in Lanne et al. (2017), i.e., $B_{y, t}=B$ for some constant matrix $B$, it follows from Lemma 2 that the structural shocks are identified up to ordering and signs. Such statistically identified shocks can then often be labelled as economic shocks based on external information (see Lanne et al., 2017). However, when the impact matrix varies in time, two complications arise. First, as the impact matrix $B_{y, t}$ is not a matrix of constant parameters but a function of parameters, it needs to be shown that the parameters in the specific functional form of $B_{y, t}$ are identified. Second, since the identification of $B_{y, t}$ at each $t$ is only up to ordering and signs of its columns, its unique identification requires that the parameters in the functional form of $B_{y, t}$ are restricted to fix the ordering and signs of the columns of $B_{y, t}$.

To address these complications, consider our functional form of $B_{y, t}$ in Equation (3.3), which defines $B_{y, t}$ as a weighted sum of the impact matrices of the regimes $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}$ with the weights given by the transition weights $\alpha_{m, t}, m=1, \ldots, M$. To fix the ordering and signs of the columns of $B_{y, t}$, such constraints need to be imposed on $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}$ that under them, the impact matrices $B_{y, t}$ before and after reordering or changing the signs of the columns of any of $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}$ are observationally distinct at some $t$. However, constraints that are not restrictive in some specifications may be overidentifying in others, while constraints sufficient in some specifications may not be identifying in others, depending on the transition weights and shock distributions. Therefore, it is

useful to divide the discussion on identification into the cases of binary (i.e., $\alpha_{m, t} \in\{0,1\}$ ) and more general transition weights.

# 3.3 Identification of the shocks in structural TVAR models 

Suppose the transition weights are binary, $\alpha_{m, t} \in\{0,1\}$, for all $t$ and $m=1, \ldots, M$, specifically being either exogenous or of the threshold form (2.3). Then at every $t$, the process is completely in one of the regimes, making the impact matrix $B_{y, t}=B_{m}$ for the active regime $m$ with $\alpha_{m, t}=1$. By Lemma 2, $B_{y, t}$ is thereby identified up to ordering and signs of its columns within each regime, and identification requires constraints that fix these orderings and signs for each regime-specific impact matrix $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}$. For simplicity, and to state the identification result under just-identifying constraints, we assume each shock $e_{i t}, i=1, \ldots, d$, follows the skewed $t$-distribution of Hansen (1994), which can flexibly capture fat tails and skewness, and nests the Gaussian distribution as a special case. The skewed $t$-distribution is described in Section 4 discussing estimation of the model parameters. ${ }^{1}$

The following proposition, which is proved in Appendix B.3, states the identification result for the TVAR model and models with exogenous binary weights.

Proposition 1. Consider the STVAR model defined in Equations (3.2) and (3.3) with $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}$ invertible; Assumption 1 and the conditions of Lemma 2 satisfied; $\alpha_{m, t}$ either of the threshold form (2.3) or exogenous (nonrandom) with $\alpha_{m, t} \in\{0,1\}$ for all $t$ and $m=1, \ldots, M$; and the shocks $e_{i t}, i=1, \ldots, d$, following the skewed $t$-distribution defined in Equation (4.1) with the parameters $\nu_{i}>2$ and $\lambda_{i} \in(-1,1)$ controlling kurtosis and skewness, respectively. Suppose the observed time series is $y_{-p+1}, \ldots, y_{0}, y_{1}, \ldots, y_{T}$, and assume the following conditions hold:
(a) the ordering and signs of the columns of $B_{1}$ are fixed,
${ }^{1}$ The identification result can be extended to other suitable shock distributions using arguments similar to those in the proof of Proposition 1 in Appendix B. 3 .

(b) $\left(\nu_{i}, \lambda_{i}\right) \neq\left(\nu_{j}, \lambda_{j}\right)$ for all $i \neq j \in\{1, \ldots, d\}$,
(c) $\lambda_{i} \neq 0$ for all $i=1, \ldots, d$.

Then, the matrices $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}$ are uniquely identified almost everywhere in $\left(y_{-p+1}, \ldots, y_{0}, y_{1}, \ldots, y_{T}\right) \in$ $\mathbb{R}^{d(T+p)}$.

Condition (a) of Proposition 1 fixes the ordering and signs of $B_{1}$, which effectively fixes the ordering and signs of the columns of $B_{2}, \ldots, B_{M}$ under Conditions (b) and (c), respectively. Any fixed ordering and signs of the columns of $B_{1}$ can be chosen without loss of generality (e.g., by making the first nonzero entry in each column is positive and ordering these entries in decreasing magnitude, given that none of them are equal). If Condition (b) fails for some $i, j \in\{1, \ldots, d\}$, the distributions of these shocks are identical, implying that fixing the ordering of the columns of $B_{1}$ does not fix the ordering of the corresponding columns of $B_{2}, \ldots, B_{M}$. In such a case, the ordering of the corresponding columns of $B_{2}, \ldots, B_{M}$ can be arbitrarily fixed without loss of generality. Similarly, if Condition (c) fails for some $i \in\{1, \ldots, d\}$ (meaning zero skewness), the signs of the corresponding columns of $B_{2}, \ldots, B_{M}$ can be arbitrarily fixed without loss of generality. The result of Proposition 1 holds only almost everywhere in $\left(y_{-p+1}, \ldots, y_{0}, y_{1}, \ldots, y_{T}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{d(T+p)}$, because in some special cases that comprise set with a Lebesgue measure zero, changing the ordering of the columns of $B_{2}, \ldots, B_{M}$ does not change the joint density of the model.

If Condition (b) or (c) is close to break, identification is weak with respect to the ordering or signs of the corresponding columns of $B_{2}, \ldots, B_{M}$, respectively. Somewhat surprisingly, our experience shows that even when Conditions (b) and (c) hold clearly, identification appears to be often weak with respect to the ordering and signs of the columns of $B_{2}, \ldots, B_{M}$, at least if the parameters are estimated by the method of maximum likelihood or penalized maximum likelihood (discussed in Section 4). Specifically, there are frequently a number of local maxima of the (penalized) loglikelihood function with (penalized) log-likelihoods close to each other, corresponding to otherwise largely similar parameter estimates but with different the ordering and signs of the columns of

$B_{2}, \ldots, B_{M}$. As discussed in Section 3.5, this weak identification should be appropriately dealt with when labelling the shocks, for instance, by combining Proposition 1 with additional identifying information.

# 3.4 Identification of the shocks in structural STVAR models 

Having established the identification result for structural TVAR models, we now consider transition weights that exhibit more variation. In particular, the transition weights are here assumed to be either exogenous (nonrandom) or logistic as defined in (2.4), so that the result of Lemma 2 establishing identification of the transition weights can be exploited. Under the conditions of the following proposition (which is proven in Appendix B.4), the matrices $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}$ are uniquely identified.

Proposition 2. Consider the STVAR model defined in Equations (3.2) and (3.3) with Assumption 1 and the conditions of Lemma 2 satisfied, and let the transition weights be either exogenous (nonrandom) or follow the logistic process defined in (2.4) (with $M=2$ assumed). Suppose the observed time series is $y_{-p+1}, \ldots, y_{0}, y_{1}, \ldots, y_{T}$, and assume the following conditions hold:
(A) the ordering and signs of the columns of $B_{1}$ are fixed, and
(B) the vector $\left(\alpha_{1, t}, \ldots, \alpha_{M, t}\right)$ takes a value for some $t$ such that none of its entries is zero.

Then, for models with logistic transition weights, the matrices $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}$ are uniquely identified almost everywhere in $\left[B_{1}: \ldots: B_{M}\right] \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times d M},\left(y_{-p+1}, \ldots, y_{0}, y_{1}, \ldots, y_{T-1}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{d(T+p-1)}$ and, if the switching variable $z_{t}$ is exogenous, $\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{T}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{T}$. For models with nonrandom exogenous transition weights, this result holds almost everywhere in $\left[B_{1}: \ldots: B_{M}\right] \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times d M}$.

Proposition 2 essentially states that if the structural shocks are independent and at most one of them is Gaussian (Assumption 1), the impact matrices $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}$, and hence, the structural shocks are

identified. The result holds only almost everywhere, because the parameters are not identified in some special cases that constitute a set with Lebesgue measure zero (see also Lemma 2).

Condition (A) of Proposition 2 states that the ordering and signs of the columns of $B_{1}$ should be fixed, which fixes the ordering and signs of the columns of $B_{g, t}$. If the shocks follow the skewed $t$-distributions defined in (4.1), any fixed ordering and signs of the columns of $B_{1}$ can be assumed without loss of generality, as reordering the columns would just reorder the shocks and swapping a sign of a column corresponds to swapping the sign of the related shock and skewness parameter. Condition (B) states that the transition weights should, for some $t$, be strictly positive for all of the regimes. If there are only two regimes, the requirement is merely that the regime-switches are not always discrete, in which case Proposition 1 would be relevant. Similarly to the structural TVAR model discussed in Section 3.3, our experience shows that identification appears to be often weak with respect to the ordering and signs of the columns of $B_{2}, \ldots, B_{M}$, which should be appropriately dealt with when labelling the shocks, as discussed in the next section.

# 3.5 Labelling the shocks and blended identification 

As in the linear SVAR model of Lanne et al. (2017), the statistically identified structural shocks do not necessarily have an economic interpretation, and labelling them as economic shocks requires external information. Our identification method, nonetheless, facilitates identifying structural shocks with time-varying impact effects without imposing restrictions on the impact responses of the variables. This is a major advantage compared to statistical identification by heteroscedasticity that restricts how the impact responses may vary over time (see Lütkepohl and Netšunajev, 2017).

Labelling the shocks based on the estimates of the impact matrices $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}$ might not always be straightforward, as the same shock needs to be associated with the same column of the impact matrix $B_{m}$ in all regimes. For example, if a positive supply shock increases output and decreases

prices on impact, and it should do so in all regimes, labelling the $i$ th shock as the supply shock requires the $i$ th column of all $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}$ to satisfy such signs. However, as discussed in Sections 3.3 and 3.4, identification can be weak with respect to the ordering and signs of the columns of $B_{2}, \ldots, B_{M}$, which should be appropriately accounted for when labelling the shocks.

Assuming that the parameters are estimated by the method of maximum likelihood (ML) or penalized maximum likelihood (PML) described in Section 4, weak identification often results in multiple local maxima of the (penalized) log-likelihood function with the related (penalized) loglikelihoods close to each other. If identification is weak with respect to the ordering and signs of the columns of $B_{2}, \ldots, B_{M}$, these local solutions often correspond to otherwise largely similar parameter estimates but with different ordering and signs of the columns of $B_{2}, \ldots, B_{M}$.

To formally obtain the local solution that facilitates labelling the shock of interest to the same column of the impact matrix in all regimes, we recommend employing a "blended identification" strategy that combines identification by non-Gaussianity with additional identifying information (cf. Carriero et al., 2024). As a concrete example, if a supply shock should increase output and decrease prices at impact in all regimes, selecting the best local solution where the same column in all $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}$ satisfies such signs amounts to combining identification by non-Gaussianity with the appropriate short-run sign restrictions. In addition to short-run sign restrictions, also other types of information can be exploited in blended identification, including narrative restrictions and testable zero impact effect restrictions, for instance.

# 4 Estimation
### 4.1 Maximum likelihood estimation and ergodic stationarity

The parameters of the structural STVAR models discussed in Section 3 can be estimated by the method of maximum likelihood (ML), which amounts to maximizing the log-likelihood function

over the parameter space. To obtain a well-behaving estimator with desirable asymptotic properties such as consistency, the parameter space is often restricted to the region where the model is ergodic stationary. Based on the results of Saikkonen (2008) (see also Kheifets and Saikkonen, 2020), we show in Appendix A (Theorem A.1) that when the transition weights $\alpha_{m, t}$ are $\mathcal{F}_{t-1}$-measurable functions of $\left\{y_{t-j}, j=1, \ldots, p\right\}$, a sufficient condition for ergodic stationarity is that the joint spectral radius of the companion form AR matrices of the regimes is strictly less than one. But since this condition is computationally demanding to verify (e.g., Chang and Blondel, 2013), it is not very practical to use it to restrict the parameter space in estimation. Therefore, we restrict the parameter space with the more easily verifiable condition that the usual stability condition is satisfied for each of the regimes (Condition A. 1 in Appendix A), as it is necessary for the sufficient condition. After estimation, the sufficient condition can be checked for the solutions of interest.

Maximizing the log-likelihood function (presented in Section 4.2) can be challenging in practice due to its high multimodality, induced by the nonlinear dynamics. Imposing the stability condition can make estimation particularly difficult when the data is persistent, as in such cases numerical optimization algorithms frequently gravitate to the boundary of the parameter space, where they perform poorly and are not often even able to converge to a local maximum. To overcome this issue, we propose to allow for unstable estimates and to maximize the penalized log-likelihood function, obtained by adding a penalty term to the log-likelihood function that penalizes parameter values falling outside or close to the boundary of the stability region. In this way, the optimization algorithm can explore the parameter space also outside the stability region, facilitating improved performance, while sufficient penalization eventually steers the optimization algorithm back to the stability region.

Penalized likelihood -based estimation has been previously applied to time series models by Nielsen and Rahbek (2024). They impose nonnegativity constraints in the autoregressive conditional heteroscedasticity model, allowing the estimation algorithm to explore the boundary of the parameter space. Nielsen and Rahbek (2024) use penalization also to determine which parameters should be

# 4.2 The penalized log-likelihood function 

Before introducing the penalized log-likelihood function, the log-likelihood function is presented. We assume that each shock $e_{i t}, i=1, \ldots, d$, follow the skewed $t$-distribution introduced by Hansen (1994) with zero mean, unit variance, $\nu_{i}>2$ degrees of freedom, and skewness controlled by the parameter $\lambda_{i} \in(-1,1)$. The density function of the skewed $t$-distribution, $s t\left(\cdot ; \nu_{i}, \lambda_{i}\right)$, is given as (Hansen, 1994, Equations (10)-(13)):

$$
s t\left(e_{i t} ; \nu_{i}, \lambda_{i}\right)=b_{i} c_{i}\left(1+\frac{1}{\nu_{i}-2}\left(\frac{b_{i} e_{i t}+a_{i}}{1-\mathbb{1}\left\{e_{i t}<-a_{i} / b_{i}\right\} \lambda_{i}+\mathbb{1}\left\{e_{i t} \geq-a_{i} / b_{i}\right\} \lambda_{i}}\right)^{2}\right)^{-(\nu_{i}+1) / 2}
$$

where $\mathbb{1}\left\{e_{i t}<-a_{i} / b_{i}\right\}$ is an indicator function that takes the value one if $e_{i t}<-a_{i} / b_{i}$ and zero otherwise, and $\mathbb{1}\left\{e_{i t} \geq-a_{i} / b_{i}\right\}$ is an indicator function that takes the value one if $e_{i t} \geq-a_{i} / b_{i}$ and zero otherwise. The constants $a_{i}, b_{i}$, and $c_{i}$ are defined as $a_{i}=4 \lambda_{i} c_{i}\left(\frac{\nu_{i}-2}{\nu_{i}-1}\right), b_{i}=\left(1+3 \lambda_{i}^{2}-a_{i}^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}$, and $c_{i}=\frac{\Gamma\left(\frac{\nu_{i}+1}{2}\right)}{\left(\pi\left(\nu_{i}-2\right)\right)^{1 / 2} \Gamma\left(\frac{\nu_{i}}{2}\right)}$, where $\Gamma(\cdot)$ is the Gamma function.

Indexing the observed data as $y_{-p+1}, \ldots, y_{0}, y_{1}, \ldots, y_{T}$, the conditional log-likelihood function, conditional on the initial values $\boldsymbol{y}_{0}=\left(y_{0}, \ldots, y_{-p+1}\right)$, is given as

$$
L(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\sum_{t=1}^{T} \log \left(\left|\operatorname{det}\left(B_{y, t}\right)\right|^{-1} \prod_{i=1}^{d} s t\left(I_{d, i}^{\prime} B_{y, t}^{-1}\left(y_{t}-\mu_{y, t}\right) ; \nu_{i}, \lambda_{i}\right)\right)
$$

where $I_{d, i}$ is the $i$ th column of the $d$-dimensional identity matrix, $\mu_{y, t}$ is defined in Section 2 and $B_{y, t}$ in Equation (3.3). The parameters of the model are collected to the vector $\boldsymbol{\theta}=\left(\phi_{1}, \ldots, \phi_{M}\right.$, $\left.\varphi_{1}, \ldots, \varphi_{M}, \sigma, \alpha, \nu\right)$, where $\varphi_{m}=\left(\operatorname{vec}\left(A_{m, 1}\right), \ldots, \operatorname{vec}\left(A_{m, p}\right)\right), m=1, \ldots, M, \sigma=\left(\operatorname{vec}\left(B_{1}\right), \ldots, \operatorname{vec}\left(B_{M}\right)\right)$, $\alpha$ contains the parameters governing the transition weights, and $\nu=\left(\nu_{1}, \ldots, \nu_{d}, \lambda_{1}, \ldots, \lambda_{d}\right)$ contains the degree-of-freedom and skewness parameters. ${ }^{2}$

[^0]:    ${ }^{2}$ With threshold (2.3) or logistic (2.4) weights, $\alpha=\left(r_{1}, \ldots, r_{M-1}\right)$ or $\alpha=(c, \gamma)$, respectively, whereas with exoge-

The penalized likelihood function is then defined as

$$
P L(\boldsymbol{\theta})=L(\boldsymbol{\theta})-P(\boldsymbol{\theta})
$$

where $L(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ is defined in (4.2) and $P(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \geq 0$ is a penalization term that penalizes the log-likelihood function from parameter values that are close to entering or are in an uninteresting region of the parameter space. To focus on avoiding unstable estimates, we define the penalization term as

$$
P(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\kappa T d \sum_{m=1}^{M} \sum_{i=1}^{d p} \max \left\{0,\left|\rho\left(\boldsymbol{A}_{m}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right)_{i}\right|-(1-\eta)\right\}^{2}
$$

where $\left|\rho\left(\boldsymbol{A}_{m}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right)_{i}\right|$ is the modulus of the $i$ th eigenvalue of the companion form AR matrix of Regime $m$, the tuning parameter $\eta \in(0,1)$ determines how close to the boundary of the stability region the penalization starts, and $\kappa>0$ determines the strength of the penalization.

Whenever the companion form AR matrix of a regime has eigenvalues greater than $1-\eta$ in modulus, the penalization term (4.4) is greater than zero, and it increases in the modulus of these eigenvalues. Our penalization term incorporates the multiplicative coefficient $T d$ in an attempt to standardize the strength of penalization with respect to the number of observations $T$ and variables $d$, as the magnitude of the log-likelihood typically increases with these quantities. In our empirical application (Section 5), we use the tuning parameter values $\eta=0.05$ and $\kappa=0.2$, thus, penalizing parameter values outside the stability region significantly, while maintaining flexibility near the boundary.

# 4.3 Three-step estimation procedure 

Lanne et al. (2017) propose a three-step estimation procedure for their linear SVAR model identified by non-Gaussianity. In the first step, least squares (LS) estimation produces preliminary
nous weights, $\alpha$ is omitted from the parameter vector.

estimates of certain parameters, which serve as initial values in numerical optimization algorithms used in the subsequent steps to maximize the log-likelihood function. The nonlinear dynamics of our structural STVAR model, however, add substantial challenges to the estimation problem by inducing a high number of modes to the (penalized) log-likelihood function. To address these challenges, we propose a modified version of the three-step estimation procedure in which multimodality is explicitly taken into account.

Our three-step estimation procedure proceeds with the following steps:

1. Estimate the autoregressive and weight function parameters $\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1} \equiv\left(\phi_{1}, \ldots, \phi_{M}, \varphi_{1}, \ldots, \varphi_{M}, \alpha\right)$ by the method of (penalized) nonlinear least squares (NLS) (see Appendix C for details). Denote this estimate of $\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}$ as $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{1}^{N L S}$.
2. Estimate the error distribution parameters $\boldsymbol{\theta}_{2} \equiv(\sigma, \nu)$ by (penalized) ML with a genetic algorithm conditionally on the (penalized) NLS estimate $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{1}^{N L S}$. Denote the obtained estimate of $\boldsymbol{\theta}_{2}$ as $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{2}^{G A}$.
3. Estimate the full parameter vector $\boldsymbol{\theta}=\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}, \boldsymbol{\theta}_{2}\right)$ by (penalized) ML by initializing a gradient based optimization algorithm from $\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{1}^{N L S}, \hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{2}^{G A}\right)$.

Step 1 obtains initial estimates for the AR and weight function parameters, and it is comparable to Step 1 of Lanne et al. (2017) but with the nonlinearity of the model explicitly accounted for. Notably, the NLS estimation often produces estimates that do not satisfy the usual stability condition for each of the regimes, and thus allowing for instability (but penalizing it) facilitates utilization of the NLS estimates in our three-step procedure. Step 2 is comparable to Step 2 of Lanne et al. (2017), but the multimodality of the (penalized) log-likelihood function is taken into account by making use of a robust estimation algorithm that is able to escape from local maxima. Step 3 finalizes the estimation by initializing a standard gradient based optimization algorithm from the initial estimates obtained from the previous steps, often converging to a nearby local maximum of the (penalized) log-likelihood function.

Due to the high multimodality of the (penalized) log-likelihood function, Steps 2 and 3 should be ran a large number times to improve the reliability of the results. Since multiple estimation rounds are run, the estimation procedure produces a set of estimates, presumably corresponding to different local maximums of the (penalized) log-likelihood function. If there are multiple solutions with (penalized) log-likelihoods almost equal to the greatest found (penalized) log-likelihood, the blended identification procedure discussed in Section 3.5 can be employed to obtain the best local solution that facilitates labelling the shocks of interest. The proposed three-step estimation procedure is implemented in the accompanying R package sstvars (Virolainen, 2025a), which is available via the CRAN repository.

To assess the performance of the penalized maximum likelihood (PML) estimator as well as our three-step estimation procedure, we conduct a small-scale Monte Carlo study, which is discussed in detail in Appendix D. Since estimation is computationally demanding, we consider simple bivariate (structural) TVAR and LSTVAR models with $p=1$ and $M=2$. To evaluate how the PML estimator performs when the AR matrices are in the penalization region, we consider two specifications of both TVAR and LSTVAR models: one where the AR matrices are well inside the stability region and one where they lie clearly in the region where the penalization term is strictly positive.

According to the results (see Tables D. 2 and D. 3 in Appendix D for details), estimation accuracy is slightly better when the AR matrices are inside the stability region, but even when they are in the penalization region, the estimators of the AR matrices exhibit only minor small-sample bias. Additionally, estimation accuracy appears to be slightly higher for the TVAR models compared to the LSTVAR models. While for most of the parameters there is only very slight bias, we find a notable upward small-sample bias for the scale parameter, for the degrees-of-freedom parameter whose true value is not small, and for the first entry in each impact matrix. The upward biases in the scale and not-small degrees-of-freedom parameters can both be explained by weak discrimination between large and very large estimates, as large values already imply nearly discrete

regime-switches and near-Gaussian distributions, respectively. The upward bias in the first entry of each impact matrix, in turn, could be explained by its sensitivity to extreme values induced by the related particularly heavy tailed skewed $t$-distribution. Nonetheless, the bias diminishes for all of the parameters as the sample size increases. Since also the standard deviations of the estimates diminish as the sample size increases, our results are in line with consistency of the PML estimator. Overall, the performance of the proposed PML estimator and the three-step estimation procedure seems reasonable.

# 5 Empirical application 

Our empirical application studies the macroeconomic effects of climate policy uncertainty (CPU). In the related literature, Fried et al. (2022) develop a dynamic general equilibrium model incorporating beliefs about future climate policy, and find that an increased climate policy transition risk shifts investments toward cleaner capital while reducing total investments and output. Khalil and Strobel (2023) reach similar conclusions in their dynamic stochastic general equilibrium (DSGE) model, attributing the effects to financial institutions' aversion to uncertainty. Huang and Punzi (2024) also use a DSGE model and find that CPU shocks cause firms to delay investments, reducing output and increasing inflation, which is supported by results from their recursively identified Bayesian VAR.

We are interested in studying how the effects of the CPU shock vary depending on the level of general economic policy uncertainty (EPU). Such variation can be accommodated in our structural STVAR model by specifying a logistic transition weight function with the (lagged) level of EPU as the switching variable. This approach allows us to capture potential nonlinearities and regimedependent effects, providing more detailed results on the macroeconomic effects of the CPU shock than linear SVAR analysis.

# 5.1 Data 

We consider a monthly U.S. dataset consisting of six variables and covering the time period from 1987:4 to 2024:12. Following Khalil and Strobel (2023) and Huang and Punzi (2024), we measure CPU with the climate policy uncertainty index (CPUI) of Gavriilidis (2021), which is constructed based on the amount of newspaper coverage on climate policy uncertainty topics. The availability of the CPUI data determines the beginning of our sample period. In order to control for general economic policy uncertainty, we also include the economic policy uncertainty index (EPUI) (Baker et al., 2016), which is based on newspaper coverage on topics related to economic policy uncertainty as well as on components quantifying the present value of future scheduled tax code expirations and disagreement among professional forecasters over future government purchases and consumer prices.

As a measure of real economic activity, we include the log of industrial production index (IPI), which is detrended by taking first differences. For measuring the price level, we use the logs of consumer price index (CPI) and producer price index (PPI), likewise detrended by taking first differences. Finally, we measure the monetary policy stance with the effective Federal funds rate that is replaced by the Wu and Xia (2016) shadow rate for the zero-lower-bound periods (RATE). The series of the included variables are presented in Figure 1. ${ }^{3}$

We employ the logistic transition weights with two regimes (Anderson and Vahid, 1998) given in Equation (2.4). They facilitate smooth transitions between the regimes and enable the analysis of how the effects of the CPU shock vary depending

# 5.3 Generalized impulse response functions 

The effects of the shocks in our structural LSTVAR model may depend on the initial state of the economy as well as on the sign and size of the shock, which makes the conventional way of calculating impulse responses unsuitable. Therefore, we consider the general impulse response function (GIRF) (Koop, Pesaran, and Potter, 1996) that accommodates such features and is defined as

$$
\operatorname{GIRF}\left(h, \delta_{i}, \mathcal{F}_{t-1}\right)=\mathrm{E}\left[y_{t+h} \mid \delta_{i}, \mathcal{F}_{t-1}\right]-\mathrm{E}\left[y_{t+h} \mid \mathcal{F}_{t-1}\right]
$$

where $h$ is the horizon. The first term on the right side of (5.1) is the expected realization of the process at time $t+h$ conditionally on a structural shock of sign and size $\delta_{i} \in \mathbb{R}$ in the $i$ th element of $e_{t}$ at time $t$ and the previous observations. The latter term on the right side is the expected realization of the process conditionally on the previous observations only. The GIRF thus expresses the expected difference in the future outcomes when the $i$ th structural shock of sign and size $\delta_{i}$ arrives at time $t$ as opposed to all shocks being random. The GIRFs also facilitate tracking the effects of the shock on the transition weights $\alpha_{m, t}, m=1, \ldots, M$, by replacing $y_{t+h}$ with $\alpha_{m, t+h}$ on the right side of Equation (5.1).

Due to the $p$-step Markov property of our structural LSTVAR model, conditioning on the previous $p$ observations, $\boldsymbol{y}_{t-1}=\left(y_{t-1}, \ldots, y_{t-p}\right)$, is equivalent to conditioning on $\mathcal{F}_{t-1}$. To the study the state-dependence of the effects of the CPU shock, we follow a procedure similar to Lanne and Virolainen (2025) and calculate the GIRFs conditional on a given regime dominating when the shock arrives. Specifically, for each Regime $m \in\{1,2\}$, we take all the length $p$ histories $\boldsymbol{y}_{t-1}$ from the data for which the corresponding transition weight $\alpha_{m, t}$ is greater than 0.75 , indicating

Finally, GIRFs corresponding to shocks of different sign and size are made comparable by scaling them to correspond to a 5 point instantaneous increase of CPUI.

The distribution of the GIRFs in each regime is illustrate in a so-called "shotgun plot" in Figure 2, which depicts each GIRF using a level of opacity such that the darkness of a region displays the concentration of GIRFs in it (cf. Lanne and Virolainen, 2025). The response of CPUI to a positive

CPU shock follows a similar pattern in both regimes in the vast majority of the GIRFs, while EPUI temporarily increases in the Low EPU Regime and decreases in the High EPU Regime. A possible explanation for the decrease in the EPUI in the High EPU Regime could be that under already heightened EPU, an unexpected increase in CPU may induce a shift in focus from broader economic policy issues to climate policy.

Consistent with the previous literature (Fried et al., 2022, Khalil and Strobel, 2023, and Huang and Punzi, 2024), a positive CPU shock decreases production in both regimes. Huang and Punzi (2024) attribute the decrease in production to firms postponing investments, whereas Fried et al. (2022) and Khalil and Strobel (2023) consider mechanisms that shift investments toward cleaner capital. Although many of the GIRFs exhibit a short-term increase of IPI in the High EPU Regime, the negative long-term response of IPI seems, on average, roughly similar in both of the regimes.

In both regimes, a positive CPU shock increases consumer prices, in line with Huang and Punzi (2024) and Khalil and Strobel (2023). Huang and Punzi (2024) found that a positive CPU shock increases inflation by acting as a negative supply shock, whereas according to Khalil and Strobel (2023), a positive CPU shock may decrease aggregate demand due to risk-averse households raising savings, while firms raise their prices pre-emptively to lower the probability of being stuck with a negative markup. However, we find that the inflationary effects are stronger in the High EPU Regime than in the Low EPU Regime. One possible explanation is that the firms are more risk averse in the periods of high EPU, and thereby react more sensitively. Producer prices, in turn, mostly decrease in the Low EPU Regime but increase in the High EPU Regime.

The response of the interest rate variable seems consistent with the inflationary effects of the CPU shock: it increases in both regimes, but clearly more so in the High EPU Regime. Finally, consistent with the GIRFs of EPUI, a positive CPU shock temporarily increases the transition weights of the High EPU Regime in the periods of low EPU, while the effect is opposite in the periods of high EPU. Overall, our results suggest that a positive CPU shock decreases production and increases inflation in both regimes, but its inflationary effects are stronger in the periods of high EPU than in

times of low EPU.

# 6 Conclusion 

Linear structural vector autoregressive models can be identified statistically by non-Gaussianity without imposing restrictions on the model if the shocks are mutually independent and at most one of them is Gaussian (Lanne et al., 2017). We have shown that this result extends to structural threshold and smooth transition vector autoregressive models incorporating a time-varying impact matrix defined as a weighted sum of the impact matrices of the regimes. The weights of the impact matrices are the transition weights of the regimes, which we assume to be either exogenous, logistic, or of the threshold form, but our results can be generalized to other suitable weight functions as well. Thus, the types of transition weights typically used in macroeconomic applications are accommodated.

In addition to establishing the identification of the shocks, we have discussed the problem of labelling them, and employed blended identification (cf. Carriero et al., 2024) to address weak identification with respect to the ordering and signs of the columns of the regime-specific impact matrices. We have proposed estimating the model parameters by the method of penalized maximum likelihood, and introduced a three-step estimation procedure by adapting the approach of Lanne et al. (2017) to nonlinear SVAR models. Building on the results of Saikkonen (2008), we have also provided a sufficient condition for ergodic stationarity of our structural STVAR model. The introduced methods have been implemented in the accompanying R package sstvars (Virolainen, 2025a), which is available via the CRAN repository.

In an empirical application to U.S. data from 1987:4 to 2024:12, we have studied the macroeconomic effects of the climate policy uncertainty shock using a two-regime logistic STVAR model. As a measure of climate policy uncertainty, we employed the CPU index (Gavriilidis, 2021) constructed based on the amount of newspaper coverage on climate policy uncertainty topics. To

distinguish between periods low and high economic policy uncertainty, we used the first lag of the EPU index (Baker et al., 2016) as the switching variable. Our results are in line with the previous literature suggesting that a positive CPU shock decreases production (Fried et al., 2022, Khalil and Strobel, 2023, and Huang and Punzi, 2024) and increases inflation (Khalil and Strobel, 2023, and Huang and Punzi, 2024). However, we found that while a positive CPU shock decreases production and increases inflation in times of both low and high EPU, its inflationary effects are stronger during the periods of high EPU.

# A Stationarity and ergodicity 

Establishing stationarity and ergodicity of the model is a common practice in time series econometrics, as it facilitates obtaining desirable asymptotic properties such as consistency of the estimator. Saikkonen (2008) derives a sufficient condition for ergodic stationarity of the smooth transition vector error correction (STVEC) model. Kheifets and Saikkonen (2020) make use of the results of Saikkonen (2008) to show that the stationarity condition readily applies for a STVAR model that can be obtained as a special case of the STVEC model of Saikkonen (2008). However, in both Saikkonen (2008) and Kheifets and Saikkonen (2020), the conditional covariance matrix of the process is defined as a weighted sum of positive definite error term covariance matrices of the regimes. As discussed in Section 3.1, the conditional covariance matrix (3.4) of our structural STVAR model has a different form, and therefore, our model is not nested to the model of Saikkonen (2008). The applicability of the results of Saikkonen (2008) also requires that the weights are not exogenous but functions of the preceding $p$ observations (the time $t$ weights are allowed to depend on the time $t$ observation of an IID process independent of $e_{t}$, but we do not discuss this option further, as it violates our assumption of $\mathcal{F}_{t-1}$-measurable or nonrandom weights). Nonetheless, we will show in this section that the stationarity condition applies to our model as well.

The sufficient stationarity condition is expressed in terms of the joint spectral radius (JSR) of certain matrices. The JSR of a finite set of square matrices $\mathcal{A}$ is defined by

$$
\rho(\mathcal{A})=\limsup _{j \rightarrow \infty}\left(\sup _{A \in \mathcal{A}^{j}} \rho(A)\right)^{1 / j}
$$

where $\mathcal{A}^{j}=\left\{A_{1} A_{2} \ldots A_{j}: A_{i} \in \mathcal{A}\right\}$ and $\rho(A)$ is the spectral radius of the square matrix $A$.

Consider the companion form AR matrices of the regimes defined as

$$
\boldsymbol{A}_{m}=\left[\begin{array}{cccccc}
A_{m, 1} & A_{m, 2} & \cdots & A_{m, p-1} & A_{m, p} \\
I_{d} & 0 & \cdots & 0 & 0 \\
0 & I_{d} & & 0 & 0 \\
\vdots & & \ddots & \vdots & \vdots \\
0 & 0 & \cdots & I_{d} & 0
\end{array}\right], m=1, \ldots, M
$$

The following assumption collects the sufficient conditions for establishing ergodicity, stationarity, and mixing properties of our structural STVAR model.

Assumption A.1. Suppose the following conditions hold:
(I) $\rho\left(\left\{\boldsymbol{A}_{1}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{A}_{M}\right\}\right)<1$,
(II) The distribution of the $I I D\left(0, I_{d}, \nu\right)$ random vector $e_{t}$ has a (Lebesgue) density that is bounded away from zero on compact subsets of $\mathbb{R}^{d}$.
(III) The transition weight $\alpha_{m, t}$ is an $\mathcal{F}_{t-1}$-measurable function of $\left\{y_{t-j}, j=1, \ldots, p\right\}$ for all $t$ and $m=1, \ldots, M$.

Condition (I) states that the JSR of the companion form AR matrices of the regimes is strictly less than one, and it is analogous to Condition (10) of Saikkonen (2008). Note that this condition is sufficient but not necessarily necessary for ergodic stationarity of the process (to the best of our knowledge, there does not currently exist results presenting a sufficient necessary condition for STVAR models). Condition (II) is analogous Assumption 1 of Saikkonen (2008), and it is innocuous in practice but rules out bounded error distributions, for example. Finally, Condition (III) ensures that the assumptions for the transition function imposed by Saikkonen (2008) are satisfied, ruling out nonrandom exogenous weights (which are accommodated by our identification results).

The following theorem, which is analogous to Theorem 1 in Saikkonen (2008) and Theorem 1 in Kheifets and Saikkonen (2020), states the results.

Theorem A.1. Consider the STVAR process $y_{t}$ defined in Equations (3.2) and (3.3), and suppose Assumptions 1 and A. 1 are satisfied. Then, almost everywhere in $\left[B_{1}: \ldots: B_{M}\right] \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times d M}$, the process $\boldsymbol{y}_{t}=\left(y_{t}, \ldots, y_{t-p+1}\right)$ is a $\left(1+\|x\|^{2}\right)$-geometrically ergodic Markov chain. Thus, there exists a choice of initial values $y_{-p+1}, \ldots, y_{0}$ such that the process $y_{t}$ is strictly stationary, secondorder stationary, and $\beta$-mixing with geometrically decaying mixing numbers.

Theorem A. 1 is proven in Appendix A.1. A notable difference of Theorem A. 1 to Theorem 1 of Saikkonen (2008) (and Theorem 1 of Kheifets and Saikkonen, 2020) is that our results holds only almost everywhere in $\left[B_{1}: \ldots: B_{M}\right] \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times d M}$, while the result of Saikkonen (2008) holds everywhere. To be more specific, the result of Theorem A. 1 holds with such values of $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}$ that the resulting impact matrix $B_{y, t}=\sum_{m=1}^{M} \alpha_{m, t} B_{m}$ is invertible for all $t$, and Lemma 1 shows that this holds everywhere expect in regions of $\mathbb{R}^{d \times d M}$ that have a Lebesgue measure zero.

Assumption A. 1 is sufficient for ergodic stationarity of our structural STVAR model, but Assumption A.1(I) is computationally demanding to verify in practice (e.g., Chang and Blondel, 2013). This makes it poorly suitable for restricting the parameter space in the numerical estimation of parameters discussed in Section 4. During estimation, this condition would have to be verified repeatedly a very large of times, making the estimation extremely tedious. Hence, it is useful make use of the following condition in the estimation, which is necessary for Assumption A.1(I).

Condition A.1. $\max \left\{\rho\left(\boldsymbol{A}_{1}\right), \ldots, \rho\left(\boldsymbol{A}_{M}\right)\right\}<1$,
where $\rho\left(\boldsymbol{A}_{m}\right)$ is the spectral radius of $\boldsymbol{A}_{m}, m=1, \ldots, M$.
Condition A. 1 states that the usual stability condition is satisfied by each of the regimes. It is necessary for Assumption A.1(I), as $\max \left(\rho\left(\boldsymbol{A}_{1}\right), \ldots, \rho\left(\boldsymbol{A}_{M}\right)\right) \leq \rho\left(\left\{\boldsymbol{A}_{1}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{A}_{M}\right\}\right)$ (see Kheifets and Saikkonen, 2020, and the references therein). After estimation, Assumption A.1(I) can be checked for the solutions of interest.

Several methods have been proposed for bounding the JSR, many of which are discussed in Chang and Blondel (2013). The accompanying R package sstvars (Virolainen, 2025a) implements the

branch-and-bound method of Gripenberg (1996), but the implementation is computationally very demanding if the matrices are large and a tight bound is required. The JSR toolbox in MATLAB (Jungers, 2023), in turn, automatically combines various methods to substantially enhance computational efficiency.

# B Proofs
## B. 1 Proof of Lemma 1

Before proving Lemma 1, we establish the following lemma that is made use of in the proof:

Lemma B.1. Suppose $P\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{k}\right)$ is a finite-degree polynomial in the scalar variables $x_{i} \in \mathbb{R}$, $i=1, \ldots, k$. Denote the set of vectors $\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{k}\right)$ that satisfy the equation

$$
P\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{k}\right)=0
$$

as $\mathcal{X} \equiv\left\{\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{k}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{k} \mid P\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{k}\right)=0\right\}$. Then, the set $\mathcal{X}$ has a Lebesgue measure zero in $\mathbb{R}^{k}$, unless Equation (B.1) is identically true.

Proof. If $k=1$, the proof is trivial. Suppose $k>1$. It then follows from Implicit function theorem that in the points $x^{0}=\left(x_{1,0}, \ldots, x_{k, 0}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{k}$ where the gradient of $P\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{k}\right)$ is nonzero, the set $\mathcal{X}$ is an $k-1$-dimensional manifold locally in a neighbourhood of $x^{0}$. Because this argument applies at all points $x^{0}$ where the gradient of $P\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{k}\right)$ is nonzero, it follows that the set $\mathcal{X}$ is an $k-1$-dimensional manifold in regions where this condition holds. Therefore, Lebesque measure of the set $\mathcal{X}$ is zero in $\mathbb{R}^{k}$ in the region where the gradient of $P\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{k}\right)$ is nonzero. On the other hand, by Sard's theorem (Sard, 1994), the set of points where the gradient of $P\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{k}\right)$ is zero has a Lebesgue measure zero in $\mathbb{R}^{k}$. Since the union of two sets with a Lebesgue measure zero has a Lebesgue measure zero, these results can be combined to conclude that the $\mathcal{X}$ has a Lebesgue

measure zero in $\mathbb{R}^{k}$.

To prove Lemma 1, we start by showing that for all $\alpha_{1, t}, \ldots, \alpha_{M, t}$, the matrix $B_{y, t}=\sum_{m=1}^{M} \alpha_{m, t} B_{m}$ is invertible almost everywhere in $\left[B_{1}: \ldots: B_{M}\right] \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times d M}$. First, note that by the constraints $\sum_{m=1} \alpha_{m, t}=1$ and $\alpha_{m, t} \geq 0, m=1, \ldots, M$, we have $\alpha_{m, t}>0$ for some $m$ for all $t$. Therefore, for all $\alpha_{1, t}, \ldots, \alpha_{M, t}$, there exists invertible matrices $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}$ such that $B_{y, t}$ is invertible. The set of points $\left[B_{1}: \ldots: B_{M}\right] \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times d M}$ (or equally $\left.\left(\operatorname{vec}\left(B_{1}\right), \ldots, \operatorname{vec}\left(B_{M}\right)\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{M d^{2}}\right)$ for which $B_{y, t}$ is singular is $S_{t} \equiv\left\{\left(\operatorname{vec}\left(B_{1}\right), \ldots, \operatorname{vec}\left(B_{M}\right)\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{M d^{2}} \mid \operatorname{det}\left(\sum_{m=1}^{M} \alpha_{m, t} B_{m}\right)=0\right\}$. Since the determinant of a matrix is polynomial in the entries of that matrix, and the entries of $\sum_{m=1}^{M} \alpha_{m, t} B_{m}$ are linear combinations of the entries of $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}$, it follows that the determinant of $\sum_{m=1}^{M} \alpha_{m, t} B_{m}$ is a polynomial in the entries of $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}$. Denote this polynomial as $P_{t}\left(B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}\right) \equiv \operatorname{det}\left(\sum_{m=1}^{M} \alpha_{m, t} B_{m}\right)$. Note that whenever $\alpha_{m, t}=0$, the impact matrices $B_{m}$ of the corresponding regimes drop out from $P_{t}\left(B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}\right)$, but in this case $P_{t}\left(B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}\right)$ can still be interpreted as a polynomial in the entries of $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}$ with the multipliers of the dropped entries being zero. It then follows from Lemma B. 1 that $S_{t}$ has a Lebesgue measure zero in $\mathbb{R}^{M d^{2}}$.

Finally, note that since the above result holds for all $\alpha_{1, t}, \ldots, \alpha_{M, t}$, the set $S_{t}$ has a Lebesgue measure zero in $\mathbb{R}^{M d^{2}}$ for each $t$. Hence, the union $\cup_{t=1}^{\infty} S_{t}$ is a union of a countable number of measure zero sets and thus itself has a Lebesgue measure zero. It follows that the matrix $B_{y, t}$ is invertible for all $t$ almost everywhere in $\left[B_{1}: \ldots: B_{M}\right] \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times d M}$, concluding the proof.

# B. 2 Proof of Lemma 2 

The first part of our proof is largely similar to the proof of Proposition 1 in Lanne et al. (2017) building on results from independent component analysis (Comon, 1994). First, note that from Equation (3.2), we can rewrite the model as

$$
y_{t}-\phi_{y, t}-\boldsymbol{A}_{y, t} \boldsymbol{y}_{t-1}=B_{y, t} e_{t}
$$

where $\phi_{y, t} \equiv \sum_{m=1}^{M} \alpha_{m, t} \phi_{m}(d \times 1), \boldsymbol{A}_{y, t} \equiv\left[A_{y, t, 1}: \ldots: A_{y, t, p}\right](d \times d p)$, and $A_{y, t, i} \equiv$ $\sum_{m=1}^{M} \alpha_{m, t} A_{m, i}$ contain the time-varying AR coefficients, and $\boldsymbol{y}_{t-1}=\left(y_{t-1}, \ldots, y_{t-p}\right)$. Then, suppose Equation (B.2) holds also for some other coefficients, transition weights, impact matrix, and shocks $\tilde{\phi}_{m}, \tilde{A}_{m, 1}, \ldots, \tilde{A}_{m, p}, \tilde{\alpha}_{m, t}, m=1, \ldots, M, \tilde{B}_{y, t}$, and $\tilde{e}_{t}$ (and define $\tilde{\phi}_{y, t}$ and $\tilde{\boldsymbol{A}}_{y, t}$ analogously), i.e., $y_{t}-\tilde{\phi}_{y, t}-\tilde{\boldsymbol{A}}_{y, t} \boldsymbol{y}_{t-1}=\tilde{B}_{y, t} \tilde{e}_{t}$. By subtracting this identify from (B.2), we obtain

$$
\tilde{\phi}_{y, t}-\phi_{y, t}+\left(\tilde{\boldsymbol{A}}_{y, t}-\boldsymbol{A}_{y, t}\right) \boldsymbol{y}_{t-1}=B_{y, t} e_{t}-\tilde{B}_{y, t} \tilde{e}_{t}
$$

Taking conditional expectation conditional on $\mathcal{F}_{t-1}$ gives

$$
\tilde{\phi}_{y, t}-\phi_{y, t}+\left(\tilde{\boldsymbol{A}}_{y, t}-\boldsymbol{A}_{y, t}\right) \boldsymbol{y}_{t-1}=0
$$

as $E\left[B_{y, t} e_{t} \mid \mathcal{F}_{t-1}\right]=E\left[\tilde{B}_{y, t} \tilde{e}_{t} \mid \mathcal{F}_{t-1}\right]=0$ (by $e_{t} \perp \mathcal{F}_{t-1}$ and $E\left[e_{t}\right]=0$ ). By substituting this back to (B.3), we get

$$
B_{y, t} e_{t}=\tilde{B}_{y, t} \tilde{e}_{t}
$$

Since $B_{y, t}$ is invertible almost everywhere in $\left[B_{1}: \ldots: B_{M}\right] \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times d M}$ by Lemma 1, we can solve $e_{t}$ as $e_{t}=C \tilde{e}_{t}$, where $C=B_{y, t}^{-1} \tilde{B}_{y, t}$ is $\mathcal{F}_{t-1}$-measurable. By Assumption 1, the random variables $\tilde{e}_{1 t}, \ldots, \tilde{e}_{d t}$ are mutually independent and at most one of them is Gaussian. Also the random variables $e_{1 t}, \ldots, e_{d t}$ are mutually independent and at most one of them is Gaussian. Therefore, conditionally on $\mathcal{F}_{t-1}$, by Darmois-Skitovich theorem (Lemma A. 1 in Lanne et al., 2017), at most one column of $C$ may contain more than one nonzero element. Suppose, say, the $k$ th column of $C$ has at least two nonzero elements, $c_{i k}$ and $c_{j k}, i \neq j$. Then, $e_{i t}=c_{i k} \tilde{e}_{k t}+\sum_{l=1, l \neq k}^{d} c_{i l} \tilde{e}_{l t}$ and $e_{j t}=c_{j k} \tilde{e}_{k t}+\sum_{l=1, l \neq k}^{d} c_{j l} \tilde{e}_{l t}$ with $\tilde{e}_{k t}$ Gaussian (by Darmois-Skitovich theorem). This implies that $E\left[e_{i t} e_{j t}\right]=c_{i k} c_{j k} \neq 0$ (since $E\left[\tilde{e}_{k t}^{2}\right]=1$ ), so $e_{i t}$ and $e_{j t}$ are not independent, which is a contradiction. Hence, each column of $C$ has at most one nonzero element.

Now, from the invertibility of $C$ it follows that each column of $C$ as exactly one nonzero element, and for the same reason, also that each row of $C$ has exactly one nonzero element. Therefore, there

exists a permutation matrix $P$ and a diagonal matrix $D=\operatorname{diag}\left(d_{1}, \ldots, d_{d}\right)$ with nonzero diagonal elements such that $C=D P$. Together with $C=B_{y, t}^{-1} \tilde{B}_{y, t}$ this implies that $\tilde{B}_{y, t}=B_{y, t} D P$ and $\tilde{e}_{t}=P^{\prime} D^{-1} e_{t}$, concluding that $B_{y, t}$ is unique up to ordering of its columns and multiplying each column by a constant.

To complete the first part of the proof, it needs to be shown that the diagonal elements of $D$ are either 1 or -1 . By the normalization of the unit variances of $e_{t}$ and $\tilde{e}_{t}, \operatorname{Cov}\left(\tilde{e}_{t} \mid \mathcal{F}_{t-1}\right)=$ $\operatorname{Cov}\left(C e_{t} \mid \mathcal{F}_{t-1}\right)=I_{d}$, which is equivalent to $C \operatorname{Cov}\left(e_{t} \mid \mathcal{F}_{t-1}\right) C^{\prime}=I_{d}$ and thereby $C C^{\prime}=I_{d}$. By substituting $C=D P$ to this expression, we obtain $D P P^{\prime} D^{\prime}=I_{d}$ and by the orthogonality of permutation matrix $D D^{\prime}=I_{d}$. That is, $d_{i i}^{2}=1$ for all $i=1, \ldots, d$, so $d_{i i}= \pm 1$. Since diagonal elements of $D$ are, hence, either 1 or -1 , it follows that $B_{y, t}$ is unique up to ordering of its columns and changing all signs in a column almost everywhere in $\left[B_{1}: \ldots: B_{M}\right] \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times d M}$.

Threshold weights. To show the "moreover"-part, consider first the threshold transition weights defined in (2.3). Denote the partition of the time periods to the regimes as $\mathcal{T}_{m}=\left\{t: r_{m-1}<z_{t} \leq\right.$ $\left.r_{m}\right\}, m=1, \ldots, M$, where $z_{t}$ is the switching variable and $r_{0}=-\infty, r_{M}=\infty$, and $r_{1}, \ldots, r_{M-1}$ are threshold parameters, and suppose Equation (B.2) holds also for some other partition $\tilde{\mathcal{T}}_{m}=\{t$ : $\left.\tilde{r}_{m-1}<z_{t} \leq \tilde{r}_{m}\right\}, m=1, \ldots, M$. By Condition (3) of Lemma 2, the sets $\mathcal{T}_{m}$ and $\tilde{\mathcal{T}}_{m}$ are nonempty for all $m=1, \ldots, M$. That is, we assume Equation (B.4) holds for the two sets of parameters $\phi_{m}, A_{m, 1}, \ldots, A_{m, p}, m=1, \ldots, M, r_{1}, \ldots, r_{M-1}$ and $\tilde{\phi}_{m}, \tilde{A}_{m, 1}, \ldots, \tilde{A}_{m, p}, m=1, \ldots, M, \tilde{r}_{1}, \ldots, \tilde{r}_{M-1}$. At each $t$, the model reduces to a linear VAR $y_{t}=\phi_{m}+\sum_{i=1}^{p} A_{m, i} y_{t-1}+B_{m} e_{t}$ corresponding to the regime $m$ for which $r_{m-1}<z_{t} \leq r_{m}$. Consequently, Equation (B.4) can be written as

$$
\tilde{\phi}_{\tilde{m}_{t}}-\phi_{m_{t}}+\sum_{i=1}^{p}\left(\tilde{A}_{\tilde{m}_{t}, i}-A_{m_{t}, i}\right) y_{t-i}=0
$$

where $m_{t} \in\{1, \ldots, M\}$ is the regime $m$ that satisfies $r_{m-1}<z_{t} \leq r_{m}$ and $\tilde{m}_{t} \in\{1, \ldots, M\}$ is the regime $m$ that satisfies $\tilde{r}_{m-1}<z_{t} \leq \tilde{r}_{m}$ at the time $t$.

Equation (B.6) defines $d$ scalar equations such that the left side of each scalar equation is a first de-

gree polynomial in $\boldsymbol{y}_{t-1} \in \mathbb{R}^{d p}$, where, for the $j$ th equation, the coefficients are given by the $j$ th element of $\tilde{\phi}_{\tilde{m}_{t}}-\phi_{m_{t}}$ and the elements of the $j$ th rows of $\tilde{A}_{\tilde{m}_{t}, i}-A_{m_{t}, i}, i=1, \ldots, p$.
