Hence, by applying Lemma B. 1 to each scalar equation in (B.6), it can be concluded that the set of solutions to Equation (B.6) has a Lebesgue measure zero in $\mathbb{R}^{d p}$ unless it is identically true. Since Equation (B.6) is identically true if and only if $\tilde{\phi}_{\tilde{m}_{t}}=\phi_{m_{t}}$ and $\tilde{A}_{\tilde{m}_{t}, i}=A_{m_{t}, i}, i=1, \ldots, p$, and because Equation (B.6) must hold for all $t$ (thereby for all regimes), it follows that $\tilde{\phi}_{\tilde{m}}=\phi_{m}$ and $\tilde{A}_{\tilde{m}, i}=A_{m, i}$, $i=1, \ldots, p$, for all $m=1, \ldots, M$ almost everywhere in $\left(y_{-p+1}, \ldots, y_{0}, y_{1}, \ldots, y_{T-1}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{d(T+p-1)}$ (as a countable union of measure zero sets has a measure zero). It then follows from Condition (2) of Lemma 2 that once $\tilde{\phi}_{\tilde{m}}=\phi_{m}$ and $\tilde{A}_{\tilde{m}, i}=A_{m, i}, i=1, \ldots, p$, for all $m=1, \ldots, M$, the only way for these parameters to match the data almost everywhere is that the same regime index must apply for each $t$. Consequently, $\tilde{m}_{t}=m_{t}$ for all $t$, so the threshold parameters $r_{1}, \ldots, r_{M-1}$ and $\tilde{r}_{1}, \ldots, \tilde{r}_{M-1}$ imply identical partitions of the data to the regimes, $\tilde{\mathcal{T}}_{m}=\mathcal{T}_{m}$ for all $m=1, \ldots, M$ almost everywhere in $\left(y_{-p+1}, \ldots, y_{0}, y_{1}, \ldots, y_{T-1}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{d(T+p-1)}$.

Because a regime switches when (and only when) the switching variable passes one of the threshold parameter values, for a given (countable number of) observations of $z_{t}$, the threshold parameters can only be identified with the resolution determined by the spacing of the order statistics of $z_{t}$. For instance, if the $n$th $(n \in\{1, \ldots, T-1\})$ order statistic of $z_{t}$ is 1.00 , its $n+1$ th order statistic is 1.02 , and $M=2$, then all values of the threshold parameter $r_{1}$ between 1.00 and 1.02 correspond to the same model, as they all imply the same regime-switches. Hence, the identification of the threshold parameters should be understood in the sense that they are identified to be between some order statistics of the switching variable series $z_{t}$. Now, if the threshold parameter values $\tilde{r}_{1}, \ldots, \tilde{r}_{M-1}$ are between different order statistics of $z_{t}$ than $r_{1}, \ldots, r_{M-1}$, the partitions $\tilde{\mathcal{T}}_{m}$ and $\mathcal{T}_{m}$ are different for some $m \in\{1, \ldots, M\}$, in which case, by the above discussion, Equation (B.6) can only hold in sets of Lebesgue measure zero in $\left(y_{-p+1}, \ldots, y_{0}, y_{1}, \ldots, y_{T-1}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{d(T+p-1)}$. This concludes that the parameters $\phi_{m}, A_{m, 1}, \ldots, A_{m, p}, m=1, \ldots, M$ and $r_{1}, \ldots, r_{M-1}$ are uniquely identified almost everywhere in $\left(y_{-p+1}, \ldots, y_{0}, y_{1}, \ldots, y_{T-1}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{d(T+p-1)}$.

Logistic weights. Next, we show the "moreover" part for the logistic transition weights defined in (2.4) with $M=2$. Suppose Equation (B.4) holds for the two sets of parameters $\phi_{m}, A_{m, 1}, \ldots, A_{m, p}$, $m=1, \ldots, M, c, \gamma$ and $\tilde{\phi}_{m}, \tilde{A}_{m, 1}, \ldots, \tilde{A}_{m, p}, m=1, \ldots, M, \tilde{c}, \tilde{\gamma}$. The proof proceeds in the following steps: (1) we show that $\tilde{\alpha}_{m, t}=\alpha_{m, t}$ for each $t$ almost everywhere in $z_{t} \in \mathbb{R}$, (2) we use this identity to show that the parameters $c, \gamma$ are uniquely identified (almost everywhere), and then (3) we use these results to show that the intercepts and autoregression matrices are uniquely identified.

By applying Lemma B. 1 to each scalar equation in Equation (B.4), it follows that Equation (B.4) holds almost everywhere in $\boldsymbol{y}_{t-1} \in \mathbb{R}^{d p}$ if only if Equation (B.4) is identically true, that is, $\tilde{\phi}_{y, t}=$ $\phi_{y, t}$ and $\tilde{\boldsymbol{A}}_{y, t}=\boldsymbol{A}_{y, t}$ (irrespective of the weight function dynamics). By making use of the identity $\alpha_{1, t}=1-\alpha_{2, t}$, these equations can be written as

$$
\tilde{\phi}_{1}-\phi_{1}+\alpha_{2, t}\left(\phi_{1}-\phi_{2}\right)-\tilde{\alpha}_{2, t}\left(\tilde{\phi}_{1}-\tilde{\phi}_{2}\right)=0
$$

and

$$
\tilde{A}_{1, i}-A_{1, i}+\alpha_{2, t}\left(A_{1, i}-A_{2, i}\right)-\tilde{\alpha}_{2, t}\left(\tilde{A}_{1, i}-\tilde{A}_{2, i}\right)=0, \quad i=1, \ldots, p
$$

respectively.

Equations (B.7) and (B.8) define a system of $d(1+p d), d \geq 2, p \geq 1$, linear scalar equations in two variables $\alpha_{2, t}$ and $\tilde{\alpha}_{2, t}$ (interpreting the AR parameters as coefficients here). Suppose first that all of them are identically true, i.e., that all the coefficients are zero. In (B.7), this requires that $\tilde{\phi}_{1}=\phi_{1}, \phi_{1}=\phi_{2}$, and $\tilde{\phi}_{1}=\tilde{\phi}_{2}$. Similarly in (B.8), zero coefficients require that $\tilde{A}_{1, i}=A_{1, i}$, $A_{1, i}=A_{2, i}$ and $\tilde{A}_{1, i}=\tilde{A}_{2, i}$ for all $i=1, \ldots, p$. But as $\phi_{1}=\phi_{2}$ and $A_{1, i}=A_{2, i}$ for all $i=1, \ldots, p$ violates Condition (2) of Lemma 2, it must be that not all scalar equations in (B.7) and (B.8) are identically true.

For each scalar equation that is not identically true, the coefficients are not all zero, and each of these scalar equations can be expressed in the form $a_{2, j} \alpha_{2, t}=a_{0, j}+a_{3, j} \tilde{\alpha}_{2, t}$ for some $a_{0, j}, a_{2, j}, a_{3, j} \in$ $\mathbb{R}$ for the $j$ th not identically true equation. If $a_{2, j}=0$, then $\tilde{\alpha}_{2, t}$ is the constant $-a_{0, j} / a_{3, j}$ for all $t$,

which violates Condition (3) of Lemma 2. Hence, $a_{2, j} \neq 0$ (in the not identically true equations), implying that $\alpha_{2, t}=a_{0, j}+a_{1, j} \tilde{\alpha}_{2, t}$, where $a_{1, j} \equiv a_{3, j} a_{2, j}^{-1}$. Thus, the solution to Equations (B.7) and (B.8) must satisfy this relationship (for all $j$ ).

Making the dependence of the transition weights of $z_{t}$ explicit in the notation, suppose $\alpha_{2, t}\left(z_{t}\right)=$ $a_{0, j}+a_{1, j} \tilde{\alpha}_{2, t}\left(z_{t}\right)$ holds in a set of positive Lebesque measure in $z_{t} \in \mathbb{R}$. Since $\alpha_{2, t}\left(z_{t}\right)$ and $\tilde{\alpha}_{2, t}\left(z_{t}\right)$ are logistic, $\alpha_{2, t}\left(z_{t}\right)$ and $a_{0, j}+a_{1, j} \tilde{\alpha}_{2, t}\left(z_{t}\right)$ are real analytic functions. Thus, by the Identity theorem, we have that $\alpha_{2, t}\left(z_{t}\right)=a_{0, j}+a_{1, j} \tilde{\alpha}_{2, t}\left(z_{t}\right)$ for all $z_{t}$. Since this must hold for all $z_{t}$, it follows from $\lim _{z_{t} \rightarrow-\infty} \alpha_{2, t}\left(z_{t}\right)=0$ and $\lim _{z_{t} \rightarrow-\infty}\left(a_{0, j}+a_{1, j} \tilde{\alpha}_{2, t}\left(z_{t}\right)\right)=a_{0, j}$ that $a_{0, j}=0$. Similarly, assuming $a_{1, j} \neq 0$, it follows from $a_{0, j}=0, \lim _{z_{t} \rightarrow+\infty} \alpha_{2, t}\left(z_{t}\right)=1$, and $\lim _{z_{t} \rightarrow+\infty}\left(a_{0, j}+a_{1, j} \tilde{\alpha}_{2, t}\left(z_{t}\right)\right)=a_{0, j}+a_{1, j}$ that $a_{1, j}=1$. If $a_{1, j}=0$, then clearly $\alpha_{2, t}\left(z_{t}\right)=a_{0, j}+a_{1, j} \tilde{\alpha}_{2, t}\left(z_{t}\right)$ holds only in the limit $z_{t} \rightarrow-\infty$, and thereby not in a set of positive Lebesgue measure. Thus, it must be that $a_{0, j}=0$ and $a_{1, j}=1$ in sets of positive Lebesgue measure, concluding that $\alpha_{2, t}\left(z_{t}\right)=\tilde{\alpha}_{2, t}\left(z_{t}\right)$ almost everywhere in $z_{t} \in \mathbb{R}$.

Next, we make use of the identity $\alpha_{2, t}\left(z_{t}\right)=\tilde{\alpha}_{2, t}\left(z_{t}\right)$ to show that $\tilde{c}=c$ and $\tilde{\gamma}=\gamma$. By substituting the logistic weight function and simplifying, the identity $\alpha_{2, t}\left(z_{t}\right)=\tilde{\alpha}_{2, t}\left(z_{t}\right)$ can be expressed in the form

$$
(\tilde{\gamma}-\gamma) z_{t}=\tilde{\gamma} \tilde{c}-\gamma c
$$

If $\tilde{\gamma}=\gamma$, it follows that $\tilde{c}=c$. If $\tilde{\gamma} \neq \gamma$, Equation (B.9) has only one solution, namely, $z_{t}=$ $(\tilde{\gamma}-\gamma)^{-1}(\tilde{\gamma} \tilde{c}-\gamma c)$. Thus, $\tilde{\gamma}=\gamma$ and $\tilde{c}=c$ almost everywhere in $\boldsymbol{y}_{t-1} \in \mathbb{R}^{d p}$ and $z_{t} \in \mathbb{R}$.

We have shown that for each $t, \tilde{\gamma}=\gamma$ and $\tilde{c}=c$ holds almost everywhere in $\boldsymbol{y}_{t-1} \in \mathbb{R}^{d p}$ and $z_{t} \in \mathbb{R}$. If the $z_{t}$ is a function of $\boldsymbol{y}_{t-1}$ (rather than exogenous), we have that $\tilde{\gamma}=\gamma$ and $\tilde{c}=c$ almost everywhere in $\boldsymbol{y}_{t-1} \in \mathbb{R}^{d p}$ (as a countable union of measure zero sets has a measure zero). Since this holds for each $t$, combining it for $t=1, \ldots, T$ yields that $\tilde{\gamma}=\gamma$ and $\tilde{c}=c$ almost everywhere in $\left(y_{-p+1}, \ldots, y_{0}, y_{1}, \ldots, y_{T-1}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{d(T+p-1)}$ and $\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{T}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{T}$. If $z_{t}$ is a function of $\boldsymbol{y}_{t-1}$, this result holds almost everywhere in $\left(y_{-p+1}, \ldots, y_{0}, y_{1}, \ldots, y_{T-1}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{d(T+p-1)}$.

Before showing that the parameters $\phi_{m}, A_{m, 1}, \ldots, A_{m, p}, m=1,2$, are identified, we present the following lemma that is used in the proof:

Lemma B.2. Consider the $T$ linear equations in $M$ variables

$$
\alpha_{1, t} x_{1}+\ldots+\alpha_{M, t} x_{M}=c_{t}, \quad t=1, \ldots, T
$$

where $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{M}$ are scalar variables, and $\alpha_{1, t}, \ldots, \alpha_{M, t}$ and $c_{t}$ are scalar constants. Suppose there exists $M$ indices $t_{1}, \ldots, t_{M} \in\{1, \ldots, T\}$ such that the corresponding coefficient vectors $\left(\alpha_{1, t_{i}}, \ldots, \alpha_{M, t_{i}}\right), i=1, \ldots, M$, are linearly independent. Then, there exists at most one solution to the system of linear equations (B.10).

Proof. By assumption, there exists $M$ indices $t_{1}, \ldots, t_{M}$ such that the coefficient vectors $\left(\alpha_{1, t_{i}}, \ldots, \alpha_{M, t_{i}}\right)$, $i=1, \ldots, M$, are linearly independent. Now, the rows of the $(M \times M)$ matrix

$$
A^{\alpha} \equiv\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
\alpha_{1, t_{1}} & \cdots & \alpha_{M, t_{1}} \\
\vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\
\alpha_{1, t_{M}} & \cdots & \alpha_{M, t_{M}}
\end{array}\right]
$$

are linearly independent, and thus $A^{\alpha}$ is invertible. The $M$ linear equations corresponding to these indices form the system $A^{\alpha} x=c$, where $x=\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{M}\right)$ and $c=\left(c_{t_{1}}, \ldots, c_{t_{M}}\right)$. Because $A^{\alpha}$ is invertible, this system has exactly one solution.

Now, any solution $x$ of the full system (B.10) for $t=1, \ldots, T$ must satisfy the above subsystem, which has exactly one solution. Therefore, the full system (B.10) has at most one solution.

We have established that $\tilde{\gamma}=\gamma$ and $\tilde{c}=c$ (and $\alpha_{2, t}\left(z_{t}\right)=\tilde{\alpha}_{2, t}\left(z_{t}\right)$ for all $t$ ) almost everywhere in $\left(y_{-p+1}, \ldots, y_{0}, y_{1}, \ldots, y_{T-1}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{d(T+p-1)}$ and, if the switching variable $z_{t}$ is exogenous, $\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{T}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{T}$. Using these identities, Equations (B.7) and (B.8) simplify to

$$
\left(1-\alpha_{2, t}\right) \tilde{\phi}_{1}+\alpha_{2, t} \tilde{\phi}_{2}=\left(1-\alpha_{2, t}\right) \phi_{1}+\alpha_{2, t} \phi_{2}
$$

and

$$
\left(1-\alpha_{2, t}\right) \tilde{A}_{1, i}+\alpha_{2, t} \tilde{A}_{2, i}=\left(1-\alpha_{2, t}\right) A_{1, i}+\alpha_{2, t} A_{2, i}, \quad i=1, \ldots, p
$$

respectively. Treating the parameters $\phi_{m}, A_{m, 1}, \ldots, A_{m, p}, m=1,2$, and $c, \gamma$, as well as ( $\mathcal{F}_{t-1^{-}}$ measurable or nonrandom) transition weights $\alpha_{2, t}$ as coefficients here, at each $t$, each scalar equation in (B.12)-(B.13) is a linear equation in two variables given by the corresponding entries of $\tilde{\phi}_{m}, \tilde{A}_{m, 1}, \ldots, \tilde{A}_{m, p}, m=1,2$.

Each scalar equation in (B.12)-(B.13) defined together for all $t=1, \ldots, T$ defines a system of $T$ linear equations and two variables. By Condition (3) of Lemma 2 (with $M=2$ ), there exists two indices $t_{1}, t_{2} \in\{1, \ldots, T\}$ such that the corresponding coefficient vectors $\left(\alpha_{1, t_{i}}, \alpha_{2, t_{i}}\right)$, or equally $\left(1-\alpha_{2, t_{i}}, \alpha_{2, t_{i}}\right), i=1,2$, are linearly independent. Hence, it follows from Lemma B. 2 that there exists at most one solution to each such system of scalar equations, and thereby also to the system of $T d(1+p d)$ linear equations (B.12)-(B.13), $t=1, \ldots, T$, in $2 d(1+p d)$ variables. Since one solution is $\tilde{\phi}_{m}=\phi_{m}, \tilde{A}_{m, i}=A_{m, i}, i=1, \ldots, p, m=1,2$, this is the unique solution. This concludes the proof that the parameters $\phi_{m}, A_{m, 1}, \ldots A_{m, p}, m=1, \ldots, M$ and $c, \gamma$ are uniquely identified almost everywhere in $\left(y_{-p+1}, \ldots, y_{0}, y_{1}, \ldots, y_{T-1}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{d(T+p-1)}$ and, if the switching variable $z_{t}$ is exogenous, $\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{T}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{T}$.

Exogenous nonrandom weights. Suppose the transition weights $\alpha_{1, t}, \ldots, \alpha_{M, t}$ are exogenous (nonrandom). If the transition weights are binary, i.e., $\alpha_{m, t} \in\{0,1\}$ for all $m=1, \ldots, M$ and $t=1, \ldots, T$, then arguments similar to those used for threshold weights can be used to conclude that the parameters $\phi_{m}, A_{m, 1}, \ldots, A_{M, p}, m=1, \ldots, M$, are uniquely identified almost everywhere in $\left(y_{-p+1}, \ldots, y_{0}, y_{1}, \ldots, y_{T-1}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{d(T+p-1)}$.

Next, suppose the transition weights are not binary. By applying Lemma B. 1 to each scalar equation in Equation (B.4), it follows that Equation (B.4) holds almost everywhere in $\boldsymbol{y}_{t-1} \in \mathbb{R}^{d p}$ if only if Equation (B.4) is identically true, that is, $\tilde{\phi}_{y, t}=\phi_{y, t}$ and $\tilde{\boldsymbol{A}}_{y, t}=\boldsymbol{A}_{y, t}$. Substituting the exogenous weights ( $\alpha_{m, t}=\tilde{\alpha}_{m, t}$ is given for all $m=1, \ldots, M$ and $t=1, \ldots, T$ ) to these equations

yields

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sum_{m=1}^{M} \alpha_{m, t}\left(\tilde{\phi}_{m}-\phi_{m}\right) & =0, \quad \text { and } \\
\sum_{m=1}^{M} \alpha_{m, t}\left(\tilde{A}_{m, i}-A_{m, i}\right) & =0, \quad i=1, \ldots, p
\end{aligned}
$$

respectively.

Treating the parameters $\phi_{m}, A_{m, 1}, \ldots, A_{m, p}, m=1,2$, and $c, \gamma$, as well as transition weights $\alpha_{1, t}, \ldots, \alpha_{M, t}$ as constants, each scalar equations in (B.14)-(B.15) defined together for all $t=$ $1, \ldots, T$ defines a system of $T$ linear equations in $M$ variables. Therefore, arguments similar to those used for logistic weights but applied for any finite number of regimes regimes, making use of Lemma B.2, can be used to conclude that the parameters $\phi_{m}, A_{m, 1}, \ldots, A_{M, p}, m=1, \ldots, M$, are uniquely identified almost everywhere in $\left(y_{-p+1}, \ldots, y_{0}, y_{1}, \ldots, y_{T-1}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{d(T+p-1)}$.

# B. 3 Proof of Proposition 1 

We start by showing that under the conditions of Proposition 1, the ordering and signs of the columns of $B_{y, t}$ are fixed for all $t$ in the sense that models before and after reordering or changing the signs of the columns of $B_{y, t}$ at any $t$ are not observationally equivalent. Specifically, we say that two models are observational equivalent if and only if their joint densities are equal. After that, we combine this result with Lemma 2 to show that $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}$ are uniquely identified.

First, we establish the following lemma and its corollary, the latter of which is used in the proof:
Lemma B.3. Suppose $\left(\nu_{i}, \lambda_{i}\right) \neq\left(\nu_{j}, \lambda_{j}\right)$ (Condition (b) of Proposition 1). Then, $s t\left(x_{1} ; \nu_{i}, \lambda_{i}\right) \neq$ $s t\left(x_{2} ; \nu_{j}, \lambda_{j}\right)$ almost everywhere in $\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{2}$, where the density function $s t\left(\cdot ; \nu_{i}, \lambda_{i}\right)$ is given in Equation (4.1). Moreover, if $\lambda_{i} \neq 0$, then the equation $s t\left(x ; \nu_{i}, \lambda_{i}\right)=s t\left(-x ; \nu_{i}, \lambda_{i}\right)$ has at most six solutions in $x \in \mathbb{R}$, and thus, $s t\left(x ; \nu_{i}, \lambda_{i}\right) \neq s t\left(-x ; \nu_{i}, \lambda_{i}\right)$ almost everywhere in $x \in \mathbb{R}$.

Proof. Denote $f\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right) \equiv s t\left(x_{1} ; \nu_{i}, \lambda_{i}\right)-s t\left(x_{2} ; \nu_{j}, \lambda_{j}\right)$, which is not identically zero by $\left(\nu_{i}, \lambda_{i}\right) \neq$ $\left(\nu_{j}, \lambda_{j}\right)$. It is straightforward to show (by induction) that the function $s t\left(x_{i} ; \nu_{i}, \lambda_{i}\right)$, and also thereby $f\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)$, is infinitely continuously differentiable. It then follows from Implicit function theorem that in the points $x^{0}=\left(x_{1,0}, x_{2,0}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{2}$ where the gradient of $f\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)$ is nonzero, the set $\mathcal{X} \equiv$ $\left\{\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{2} \mid f\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)=0\right\}$ is a one-dimensional manifold locally in a neighbourhood of $x^{0}$. Because this argument applies at all points $x^{0}$ where the gradient of $f\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)$ is nonzero, it follows that the set $\mathcal{X}$ is a one-dimensional manifold in regions where this condition holds. Therefore, Lebesque measure of the set $\mathcal{X}$ is zero in $\mathbb{R}^{2}$ in the region where the gradient of $f\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)$ is nonzero. On the other hand, by Sard's theorem (Sard, 1994), the set of points where the gradient of $f\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)$ is zero has a Lebesgue measure zero in $\mathbb{R}^{2}$. Since the union of two sets with a Lebesgue measure zero has a Lebesgue measure zero, these results can be combined to conclude that the $\mathcal{X}$ has a Lebesgue measure zero in $\mathbb{R}^{2}$. That is, $s t\left(x_{1} ; \nu_{i}, \lambda_{i}\right)=s t\left(x_{2} ; \nu_{j}, \lambda_{j}\right)$ only on sets of zero Lebesgue measure, concluding that $s t\left(x_{1} ; \nu_{i}, \lambda_{i}\right) \neq s t\left(x_{2} ; \nu_{j}, \lambda_{j}\right)$ almost everywhere in $\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right) \in$ $\mathbb{R}^{2}$.

To prove the moreover part, suppose $\lambda_{i} \neq 0$ and $s t\left(x ; \nu_{i}, \lambda_{i}\right)=s t\left(-x ; \nu_{i}, \lambda_{i}\right)$, which simplifies to

$$
\left(\frac{b_{i} x+a_{i}}{1-\mathbb{1}\left\{x<-a_{i} / b_{i}\right\} \lambda_{i}+\mathbb{1}\left\{x \geq-a_{i} / b_{i}\right\} \lambda_{i}}\right)^{2}=\left(\frac{-b_{i} x+a_{i}}{1-\mathbb{1}\left\{-x<-a_{i} / b_{i}\right\} \lambda_{i}+\mathbb{1}\left\{-x \geq-a_{i} / b_{i}\right\} \lambda_{i}}\right)^{2}
$$

where $a_{i} \neq 0$ and $b_{i} \neq 1$. If $x<-a_{i} / b_{i}$ and $-x<-a_{i} / b_{i}$ or $x \geq-a_{i} / b_{i}$ and $-x \geq-a_{i} / b_{i}$, a direct calculation shows that the only solution to Equation (B.16) is $x=0$. If $x<-a_{i} / b_{i}$ and $-x \geq-a_{i} / b_{i}$ or $x \geq-a_{i} / b_{i}$ and $-x<-a_{i} / b_{i}$, Equation (B.16) is a second degree polynomial equation in $x$ and has thereby at most two real solutions. Combining all the four possible cases, in can be concluded that $s t\left(x ; \nu_{i}, \lambda_{i}\right)=s t\left(-x ; \nu_{i}, \lambda_{i}\right)$ has at most six solutions in $x \in \mathbb{R}$.

Corollary B.1. Suppose $D$ is a diagonal matrix with $\pm 1$ diagonal entries and $P$ is a permutation matrix, and denote by $I_{d, i}$ the ith column of the $d$-dimensional identity matrix. Moreover, suppose the entries $x$ are distinct as is and after changing any of their signs. If $\left(\nu_{i}, \lambda_{i}\right) \neq\left(\nu_{j}, \lambda_{j}\right)$ for all

$i \neq j=1, \ldots, d$ and $\lambda_{i} \neq 0$ for all $i=1, \ldots, d$, and in addition, $D \neq I_{d}$ or $P \neq I_{d}$, then

$$
\prod_{i=1}^{d} s t\left(I_{d, i}^{\prime} x ; \nu_{i}, \lambda_{i}\right) \neq \prod_{i=1}^{d} s t\left(I_{d, i}^{\prime} D P x ; \nu_{i}, \lambda_{i}\right)
$$

almost everywhere in $x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$.

Proof. Suppose $\prod_{i=1}^{d} s t\left(I_{d, i}^{\prime} x ; \nu_{i}, \lambda_{i}\right)=\prod_{i=1}^{d} s t\left(I_{d, i}^{\prime} D P x ; \nu_{i}, \lambda_{i}\right)$. Rearranging and taking logarithm yields

$$
\sum_{i=1}^{d}\left(\log s t\left(I_{d, i}^{\prime} x ; \nu_{i}, \lambda_{i}\right)-\log s t\left(I_{d, i}^{\prime} D P x ; \nu_{i}, \lambda_{i}\right)\right)=0
$$

Since $D P x$ reorders or swaps the signs of some of the elements of $x$ (but does not leave all the elements unchanged), by Lemma B. 3 (and strict monotonicity of logarithm),

$$
f_{i}(x) \equiv \log s t\left(I_{d, i}^{\prime} x ; \nu_{i}, \lambda_{i}\right)-\log s t\left(I_{d, i}^{\prime} D P x ; \nu_{i}, \lambda_{i}\right) \neq 0
$$

for at least one $i \in\{1, \ldots, d\}$ over sets of positive Lebesgue measure. Therefore, Equation (B.18) can hold almost everywhere only if the nonzero terms in the sum cancel each other out.

Denote $\mathcal{I}(x) \equiv\{i \in\{1, \ldots, d\} \mid f_{i}(x) \neq 0\}$ and $g\left(x^{*}\right) \equiv \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}} f_{i}(x)$, where $x^{*}$ is the $\left(d^{*} \times 1\right)$ dimensional $\left(d^{*} \leq d\right)$ subvector of $x$ containing the components of $x$ for which $I_{d, i}^{\prime} x \neq \pm I_{d, i}^{\prime} D P x$, $i=1, \ldots, d$ (i.e., $x^{*}$ captures all variables contributing to any nonzero $f_{i}(x)$ ). It is straightforward to show (by induction) that the function $\log s t\left(x_{i} ; \nu_{i}, \lambda_{i}\right), x_{i} \in \mathbb{R}$, is infinitely continuously differentiable. It follows that also $g\left(x^{*}\right)$ is infinitely continuously differentiable, and thus $d^{*}$ times continuously differentiable. Then, arguments based on Implicit function theorem and Sard's theorem (Sard, 1994) can be used similarly to the proof of Lemma B. 3 to conclude that the set of solutions to $g\left(x^{*}\right)=0$ has a Lebesgue measure zero in $x^{*} \in \mathbb{R}^{d^{*}}$. Hence, as sets of zero Lebesgue measure in $\mathbb{R}^{d^{*}} \subset \mathbb{R}^{d}$ have zero Lebesgue measure in $\mathbb{R}^{d}$, Equation (B.18) can hold only in sets of zero Lebesgue measure in $x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$, concluding the proof.

Condition (a) of Proposition 1 fixes the ordering and signs of the columns of $B_{1}$, so it suffices to show that under Conditions (b) and (c), changing the ordering or signs of the columns of any of $B_{2}, \ldots, B_{M}$ would change the joint density of the model. Suppose the observed time series is $y_{t-p+1}, \ldots, y_{0}, y_{1}, \ldots, y_{T}$ and denote $Y_{T}=\left(y_{1}, \ldots, y_{T}\right)$. Conditional on the initial values $y_{t-p+1}, \ldots, y_{0}$, the joint density of the model is

$$
f_{Y}\left(Y_{T}\right)=\prod_{t=1}^{T}\left(\left|\operatorname{det}\left(B_{y, t}\right)\right|^{-1} \prod_{i=1}^{d} s t\left(I_{d, i}^{\prime} B_{y, t}^{-1}\left(y_{t}-\mu_{y, t}\right) ; \nu_{i}, \lambda_{i}\right)\right)
$$

where $I_{d, i}$ is the $i$ th column of the $d$-dimensional identity matrix and $s t\left(\cdot ; \nu_{i}, \lambda_{i}\right)$ is the density function the $i$ th shock given in Equation (4.1). At each $t, B_{y, t}=B_{m}$ for the regime $m$ with $r_{m-1}<z_{t} \leq r_{m}$, where the threshold parameters, as well as $B_{y, t}$ up to ordering and signs of its columns, are identified by Lemma 2 regardless of whether $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}$ are identified. Consequently the density (B.20) can be expressed as

$$
\begin{aligned}
f_{Y}\left(Y_{T} ; B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}\right) & =\prod_{m=1}^{M} \prod_{t \in \mathcal{T}_{m}} f_{y}\left(y_{t}-\mu_{y, t} ; B_{m}\right), \text { and } \\
f_{y}\left(y_{t}-\mu_{y, t} ; B_{m}\right) & =\left|\operatorname{det}\left(B_{m}\right)\right|^{-1} \prod_{i=1}^{d} s t\left(I_{d, i}^{\prime} B_{m}^{-1}\left(y_{t}-\mu_{y, t}\right) ; \nu_{i}, \lambda_{i}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\mathcal{T}_{m}, m=1, \ldots, M$, is the set of time indices (identified by Lemma 2 almost everywhere in $\left(y_{-p+1}, \ldots, y_{0}, y_{1}, \ldots, y_{T-1}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{d(T+p-1)}$ and nonempty by Condition (3) of Lemma 2) that satisfy $r_{m-1}<z_{t} \leq r_{m}$ for the regime $m, \mu_{y, t}$ is the conditional mean of the model (identified by Lemma 2 almost everywhere in $\left(y_{-p+1}, \ldots, y_{0}, y_{1}, \ldots, y_{T-1}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{d(T+p-1)}$ ), and the dependence of the density functions $f_{Y}\left(\cdot ; B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}\right)$ and $f_{y}\left(\cdot ; B_{m}\right)$ on the impact matrices $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}$ is now made explicit in the notation (but their dependence on the other parameters is omitted).

Denote by $\boldsymbol{\tau}_{m}=\left(\tau_{m 1}, \ldots, \tau_{m d}\right)$ the permutation $\tau_{m 1}, \ldots, \tau_{m d}$ of the columns of $B_{m}$, and denote by $\boldsymbol{\iota}_{m}=\left(\iota_{m 1}, \ldots, \iota_{m d}\right)$ the sign changes $\iota_{m 1}, \ldots, \iota_{m d}$ of the columns of $B_{m}$. Moreover, denote by $B_{m}\left(\boldsymbol{\tau}_{m}, \boldsymbol{\iota}_{m}\right)$ the impact matrix $B_{m}$ corresponding to the permutation $\boldsymbol{\tau}_{m}$ and sign changes $\boldsymbol{\iota}_{m}$ of

its columns. Then, consider the permutations $\boldsymbol{\tau}_{1}, \boldsymbol{\tau}_{2}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{\tau}_{M}$ and $\boldsymbol{\tau}_{1}, \tilde{\boldsymbol{\tau}}_{2}, \ldots, \tilde{\boldsymbol{\tau}}_{M}$ as well as the sign changes $\boldsymbol{\iota}_{1}, \boldsymbol{\iota}_{2}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{\iota}_{M}$ and $\boldsymbol{\iota}_{1}, \tilde{\boldsymbol{\iota}}_{2}, \ldots, \tilde{\boldsymbol{\iota}}_{M}$.

By the invertibility of $B_{m}$, almost everywhere in $y_{t} \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$, none of the entries in $B_{m}^{-1}\left(y_{t}-\mu_{y, t}\right)$ are equal to each other as is nor after changing the signs of some of the entries. Since reordering the columns of $B_{m}$ reorders the rows of $B_{m}^{-1}$, it follows that if $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\tau}}_{m} \neq \boldsymbol{\tau}_{m}$, some of the entries in $B_{m}^{-1}\left(\boldsymbol{\tau}_{m}, \boldsymbol{\iota}_{m}\right)\left(y_{t}-\mu_{y, t}\right)$ and $B_{m}^{-1}\left(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\tau}}_{m}, \tilde{\boldsymbol{\iota}}_{m}\right)\left(y_{t}-\mu_{y, t}\right)$ are in a different order. Likewise, changing the signs of the columns of $B_{m}$ changes the signs of the rows of $B_{m}^{-1}$, it follows that if $\tilde{\iota}_{m} \neq \boldsymbol{\iota}_{m}$, some of the entries in $B_{m}^{-1}\left(\boldsymbol{\tau}_{m}, \boldsymbol{\iota}_{m}\right)\left(y_{t}-\mu_{y, t}\right)$ and $B_{m}^{-1}\left(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\tau}}_{m}, \tilde{\iota}_{m}\right)\left(y_{t}-\mu_{y, t}\right)$ have different signs (in addition to possibly being in a different order).

By Corollary B.1, different orderings and signs of the elements of $B_{m}^{-1}\left(y_{t}-\mu_{y, t}\right)$ yield different values of $\prod_{i=1}^{d} s t\left(I_{d, i}^{\prime} B_{m}^{-1}\left(y_{t}-\mu_{y, t}\right) ; \nu_{i}, \lambda_{i}\right)$ almost everywhere in $y_{t} \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ under Conditions (b) and (c) of Proposition 1. Moreover, as $\left|\operatorname{det}\left(B_{m}\right)\right|$ is invariant to the ordering and signs of the columns of $B_{m}$, it follows from that, $f_{y}\left(y_{t}-\mu_{y, t} ; B_{m}\left(\boldsymbol{\tau}_{m}, \boldsymbol{\iota}_{m}\right)\right) \neq f_{y}\left(y_{t}-\mu_{y, t} ; B_{m}\left(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\tau}}_{m}, \tilde{\iota}_{m}\right)\right)$ almost everywhere in $y_{t} \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ whenever $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\tau}}_{m} \neq \boldsymbol{\tau}_{m}$ or $\tilde{\iota}_{m} \neq \boldsymbol{\iota}_{m}$. Therefore, as $\mathcal{T}_{1}, \ldots, \mathcal{T}_{M}$ and $\mu_{y, t}, t=1, \ldots, T$ are identified almost everywhere in $\left(y_{-p+1}, \ldots, y_{0}, y_{1}, \ldots, y_{T-1}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{d(T+p-1)}$ by Lemma 2 and the shocks and thereby $y_{t}$ follow continuous distributions, we have

$$
\prod_{t \in \mathcal{T}_{m}} f_{y}\left(y_{t}-\mu_{y, t} ; B_{m}\left(\boldsymbol{\tau}_{m}\right)\right) \neq \prod_{t \in \mathcal{T}_{m}} f_{y}\left(y_{t}-\mu_{y, t} ; B_{m}\left(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\tau}}_{m}\right)\right)
$$

and thus also

$$
f_{Y}\left(Y_{T} ; B_{1}\left(\boldsymbol{\tau}_{1}\right), B_{2}\left(\boldsymbol{\tau}_{2}\right), \ldots, B_{M}\left(\boldsymbol{\tau}_{M}\right)\right) \neq f_{Y}\left(Y_{T} ; B_{1}\left(\boldsymbol{\tau}_{1}\right), B_{2}\left(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\tau}}_{2}\right) \ldots, B_{M}\left(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\tau}}_{M}\right)\right)
$$

almost everywhere in $\left(y_{-p+1}, \ldots, y_{0}, Y_{T}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{d(T+p)}$ whenever $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\tau}}_{m} \neq \boldsymbol{\tau}_{m}$ or $\tilde{\iota}_{m} \neq \boldsymbol{\iota}_{m}$ for any $m=$ $2, \ldots, M$. Since this result holds almost everywhere in $\left(y_{-p+1}, \ldots, y_{0}, Y_{T}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{d(T+p)}$, and $B_{y, t}$ is here invertible for all invertible $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}$, the result holds almost everywhere in $\left(y_{-p+1}, \ldots, y_{0}, Y_{T}\right) \in$ $\mathbb{R}^{d(T+p)}$.

By Lemma 2, $B_{y, t}$ is identified up to ordering and signs of its columns at each $t$. Thus, each impact matrix $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}$ of the regimes is identified up to ordering signs of its columns. Under the conditions of Proposition 1, the ordering and signs of the columns of $B_{1}$ are directly fixed. Moreover, by the above discussion, different permutations or sign changes of the columns of any of $B_{2}, \ldots, B_{M}$ lead to different joint densities of the model almost everywhere in $\left(y_{-p+1}, \ldots, y_{0}, Y_{T}\right) \in$ $\mathbb{R}^{d(T+p)}$, i.e., to models that are not observationally equivalent. Thus, only models corresponding to the same permutations and sign changes of the columns of $B_{2}, \ldots, B_{M}$ are observationally equivalent, implying that the matrices $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}$ are uniquely identified almost everywhere in $\left(y_{-p+1}, \ldots, y_{0}, Y_{T}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{d(T+p)}$.

# B. 4 Proof of Proposition 2 

The proof consists of two parts. First, we show that if the ordering and signs of the columns of $B_{1}$ is fixed, changing the ordering or signs of the columns of any of $B_{2}, \ldots, B_{M}$ leads to an impact matrix $B_{y, t}$ that cannot, at all $t$, be obtained by reordering or changing the signs of the columns of the original impact matrix. In other words, we show that fixing the ordering signs of the columns of $B_{1}$ effectively fixes the ordering and signs of the columns of $B_{2}, \ldots, B_{M}$ and thereby of $B_{y, t}$. Then, we make use of this result together with the result of Lemma 2 (that $B_{y, t}$ is identified up ordering and signs of its columns at each $t$ ) to show that the matrices $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}$ are uniquely identified. For models with logistic transition weights (2.4), the result holds almost everywhere in $\left[B_{1}: \cdots: B_{M}\right] \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times d M},\left(y_{-p+1}, \ldots, y_{0}, y_{1}, \ldots, y_{T-1}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{d(T+p-1)}$ and, if the switching variable $z_{t}$ is exogenous, $\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{T}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{T}$. For models with nonrandom exogenous transition weights, the result holds almost everywhere in $\left[B_{1}: \cdots: B_{M}\right] \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times d M}$.

By Lemma 2, for logistic models (2.4) (with $M=2$ ), the parameters $c, \gamma$, and threreby the transition weights $\alpha_{1, t}, \ldots, \alpha_{M, t}, t=1, \ldots, T$, are uniquely identified almost everywhere in $\left(y_{-p+1}, \ldots, y_{0}\right.$, $\left.y_{1}, \ldots, y_{T-1}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{d(T+p-1)}$ (and $\left.\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{T}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{T}\right.$ for exogenous $\left.z_{t}\right)$. With nonrandom exogenous transition weights, the identification of $\alpha_{1, t}, \ldots, \alpha_{M, t}, t=1, \ldots, T$ is given. In either case,

the transition weights can be treated as uniquely identified in the rest of the proof, where, for readability, we do not repeatedly remind that the identification holds only almost everywhere in $\left(y_{-p+1}, \ldots, y_{0}, y_{1}, \ldots, y_{T-1}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{d(T+p-1)}\left(\right.$ and $\left.\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{T}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{T}\right.$ for exogenous $\left.z_{t}\right)$.

Denote by $\boldsymbol{\tau}_{m}=\left(\tau_{m 1}, \ldots, \tau_{m d}\right)$ the permutation $\tau_{m 1}, \ldots, \tau_{m d}$ and $\boldsymbol{\iota}_{m}=\left(\iota_{m 1}, \ldots, \iota_{m d}\right)$ the sign changes $\iota_{m 1}, \ldots, \iota_{m d}$ of the columns of $B_{m}$, respectively. Moreover, denote by $B_{m}\left(\boldsymbol{\tau}_{m}, \boldsymbol{\iota}_{m}\right)$ the invertible impact matrix $B_{m}$ corresponding to the permutation $\boldsymbol{\tau}_{m}$ and sign changes $\boldsymbol{\iota}_{m}$ of its columns. Then, consider the permutations $\boldsymbol{\tau}_{1}, \boldsymbol{\tau}_{2}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{\tau}_{M}$ and $\boldsymbol{\tau}_{1}, \tilde{\boldsymbol{\tau}}_{2}, \ldots, \tilde{\boldsymbol{\tau}}_{M}$ as well the sign changes $\boldsymbol{\iota}_{1}, \boldsymbol{\iota}_{2}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{\iota}_{M}$ and $\boldsymbol{\iota}_{1}, \tilde{\boldsymbol{\iota}}_{2}, \ldots, \tilde{\boldsymbol{\iota}}_{M}$. We start by showing that $B_{y, t}(\boldsymbol{\tau}, \boldsymbol{\iota}) \equiv \alpha_{1, t} B_{1}\left(\boldsymbol{\tau}_{1}, \boldsymbol{\iota}_{1}\right)+$ $\sum_{m=2}^{M} \alpha_{m, t} B_{m}\left(\boldsymbol{\tau}_{m}, \boldsymbol{\iota}_{m}\right)$ cannot be obtained by reordering or changing the signs of the columns of $B_{y, t}(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\tau}}, \tilde{\boldsymbol{\iota}}) \equiv \alpha_{m, t} B_{1}\left(\boldsymbol{\tau}_{1}, \boldsymbol{\iota}_{1}\right)+\sum_{m=2}^{M} \alpha_{m, t} B_{m}\left(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\tau}}_{m}, \tilde{\boldsymbol{\iota}}_{m}\right)$ almost everywhere in $\left[B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}\right] \in$ $\mathbb{R}^{d \times M d}$, whenever $\boldsymbol{\tau}_{m} \neq \tilde{\boldsymbol{\tau}}_{m}$ or $\boldsymbol{\iota}_{m} \neq \tilde{\boldsymbol{\iota}}_{m}$ for any $m=2, \ldots, M$.

Suppose $\boldsymbol{\tau}_{m} \neq \tilde{\boldsymbol{\tau}}_{m}$ or $\boldsymbol{\iota}_{m} \neq \tilde{\boldsymbol{\iota}}_{m}$ for any $m=2, \ldots, M$. At each time period $t$, the impact matrix $B_{y, t}(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\tau}}, \tilde{\boldsymbol{\iota}})$ is obtained by reordering or changing the signs of the columns of $B_{y, t}(\boldsymbol{\tau}, \boldsymbol{\iota})$ if and only if

$$
\alpha_{1, t} B_{1}\left(\boldsymbol{\tau}_{1}, \boldsymbol{\iota}_{1}\right)+\sum_{m=2}^{M} \alpha_{m, t} B_{m}\left(\boldsymbol{\tau}_{m}, \boldsymbol{\iota}_{m}\right)=\left(\alpha_{1, t} B_{1}\left(\boldsymbol{\tau}_{1}, \boldsymbol{\iota}_{1}\right)+\sum_{m=2}^{M} \alpha_{m, t} B_{m}\left(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\tau}}_{m}, \tilde{\boldsymbol{\iota}}_{m}\right)\right) D_{t} P_{t}
$$

for some $(d \times d)$ diagonal matrix $D_{t}$ with $\pm 1$ diagonal elements and some $(d \times d)$ permutation matrix $P_{t}$ (that may vary in time). Rearranging the above equation gives

$$
\sum_{m=2}^{M} \alpha_{m, t}\left(B_{m}\left(\boldsymbol{\tau}_{m}, \boldsymbol{\iota}_{m}\right)-B_{m}\left(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\tau}}_{m}, \tilde{\boldsymbol{\iota}}_{m}\right) D_{t} P_{t}\right)=-\alpha_{1, t} B_{1}\left(\boldsymbol{\tau}_{1}, \boldsymbol{\iota}_{1}\right)\left(I_{d}-D_{t} P_{t}\right)
$$

Suppose first $D_{t} P_{t}=I_{d}$. Equation (B.27) then simplifies to

$$
\sum_{m=2}^{M} \alpha_{m, t}\left(B_{m}\left(\boldsymbol{\tau}_{m}, \boldsymbol{\iota}_{m}\right)-B_{m}\left(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\tau}}_{m}, \tilde{\boldsymbol{\iota}}_{m}\right)\right)=0
$$

By Condition (B) of Proposition 2, the vector $\left(\alpha_{1, t}, \ldots, \alpha_{M, t}\right)$ takes a value for some $t$ such that none

of its entries is zero. At each such time period $t$, Equation (B.27) is nontrivial, as by invertibility, none of the columns of $B_{m}$ can be equal or negatives of each other. Hence, the set of matrices $B_{2}, \ldots, B_{M}$ that satisfy Equation (B.27) forms a subspace in $\mathbb{R}^{d \times d(M-1)}$ with the dimension of this subspace being less than $(M-1) d^{2}$, as it must satisfy a nontrivial linear equation. Consequently, the set of matrices $B_{2}, \ldots, B_{M}$ that satisfy Equation (B.27) has a Lebesgue measure zero in $\left[B_{2}\right.$ : $\left.\cdots: B_{M}\right] \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times d(M-1)}$, implying that the set of matrices $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}$ satisfying this equation have a Lebesgue measure zero in $\left[B_{1}: \cdots: B_{M}\right] \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times M d}$.

Suppose then $D_{t} P_{t} \neq I_{d}$ and denote the left side of Equation (B.26) as $C_{t} \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times d}$. By Condition (B) of Proposition 2, the vector $\left(\alpha_{1, t}, \ldots, \alpha_{M, t}\right)$ takes a value for some $t$ such that none of its entries is zero. At each such time period $t$, the right side of Equation (B.26) is nonzero, thus, implying that also $C_{t}$ is not a matrix zeros. Equation (B.26) is thereby nontrivial and can be expressed as

$$
B_{1}\left(\boldsymbol{\tau}_{1}, \boldsymbol{\iota}_{1}\right)\left(I_{d}-D_{t} P_{t}\right)=\alpha_{1, t}^{-1} C_{t}
$$

The set of matrices $B_{1}$ that satisfy Equation (B.28) forms a subspace in $\mathbb{R}^{d \times d}$ with the dimension of this subspace being less than $d^{2}$, as it must satisfy a nontrivial linear equation. It follows that the set of matrices $B_{1}$ that satisfy Equation (B.28) has Lebesgue measure zero on $\mathbb{R}^{d \times d}$, and therefore, the set of matrices $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}$ that satisfy Equation (B.28) has a Lebesgue measure zero in $\left[B_{1}\right.$ : $\left.\cdots B_{M}\right] \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times M d}$.

By the above discussion, for any single transformation $D_{t} P_{t}$ of $B_{y, t}$, the set of matrices $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}$ that satisfy Equation (B.26) for any time period when all the entries of $\left(\alpha_{1, t}, \ldots, \alpha_{M, t}\right)$ are nonzero has a Lebesgue measure zero in $\left[B_{1}: \cdots: B_{M}\right] \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times M d}$. Since there exists a finite number of such transformations and a countable union of measure zero sets has a measure zero, it follows that the set of matrices $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}$ that satisfy Equation (B.27) for all $t$ has a Lebesgue measure zero in $\left[B_{1}: \cdots: B_{M}\right] \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times M d}$. This concludes that, almost everywhere in $\left[B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}\right] \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times M d}$, the matrix $B_{y, t}(\boldsymbol{\tau}, \boldsymbol{\iota})$ cannot be obtained by reordering or changing the signs of the columns of $B_{y, t}(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\tau}}, \tilde{\boldsymbol{\iota}})$ whenever $\boldsymbol{\tau}_{m} \neq \tilde{\boldsymbol{\tau}}_{m}$ or $\boldsymbol{\iota}_{m} \neq \tilde{\boldsymbol{\iota}}_{m}$ for any $m=2, \ldots, M$

Next, we make use of the above result together with Lemma 2 to show that $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}$ are uniquely identified almost everywhere in $\left[B_{1}: \cdots: B_{M}\right] \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times M d}$. Consider the impact matrix $B_{y, t}=$ $\sum_{m=1}^{M} \alpha_{m, t} B_{m}$ with some invertible $(d \times d)$ matrices $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}$. By Lemma 2, $B_{y, t}$ is uniquely identified at each $t$ up to ordering and signs of its columns (conditionally on $\mathcal{F}_{t-1}$ ). Since the ordering and signs of the columns of $B_{1}$ are fixed (Condition (A) of Proposition 2), we then obtain from the above results that almost everywhere in $\left[B_{1}: \ldots: B_{M}\right] \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times d M}$, reordering or changing the signs of the columns of $B_{2}, \ldots, B_{M}$ would, at some $t$, lead to an impact matrix that cannot obtained by reordering or changing the signs of the columns of $B_{y, t}$. Hence, models before and after reordering or changing the signs of the columns of any of $B_{2}, \ldots, B_{M}$ are not be observationally equivalent. The ordering and signs of the columns of $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}$ are thereby effectively fixed under Condition (A) of Proposition 2, implying that the ordering and signs of the columns of $B_{y, t}$ are also fixed for all $t$ (almost everywhere in $\left[B_{1}: \ldots: B_{M}\right] \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times d M}$ ). Thus, $B_{y, t}$ is uniquely identified at all $t$.

Since $B_{y, t}$ is uniquely identified and two models are observationally equivalent if and only if they are observationally equivalent at all $t$, a unique identification of the matrices $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}$ is achieved if an impact matrix that is identical to $B_{y, t}$ for all $t$ cannot be obtained with any other invertible $(d \times d)$ matrices $\tilde{B}_{1}, \ldots, \tilde{B}_{M}$. Suppose an impact matrix identical to $B_{y, t}$ for all $t$ is obtained with some invertible $(d \times d)$ matrices $\tilde{B}_{1}, \ldots, \tilde{B}_{M}$. Then,

$$
\sum_{m=1}^{M} \alpha_{m, t}\left(B_{m}-\tilde{B}_{m}\right)=0
$$

for all $t$.

Denote the $i j$ th element of $\tilde{B}_{m}$ as $\tilde{b}_{i j}^{(m)}$. At each $t$, Equation (B.29) then defines a system of linear equations involving $d^{2}$ equations and $M d^{2}$ variables $\tilde{b}_{i j}^{(m)}, j, i=1, \ldots, d, m=1, \ldots, M$. The weights $\alpha_{m, t}$ are treated as constant coefficients here (some of which may be zero), as they are predetermined at each $t$ (by $\mathcal{F}_{t-1}$-measurability or nonrandomness), and the parameters in $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}$ are also constants here.

Each scalar equation in (B.29) is a linear equation in $M$ variables. Thus, each scalar equation in (B.29) defined together for all $t=1, \ldots, T$ defines a system of $T$ linear equations and $M$ variables. By Condition (3) of Lemma 2 (assumed in Proposition 2), there exists $M$ indices $t_{1}, \ldots, t_{M} \in$ $\{1, \ldots, T\}$ such that the corresponding coefficient vectors $\left(\alpha_{1, t_{i}}, \ldots, \alpha_{M, t_{i}}\right), i=1, \ldots, M$, are linearly independent. Hence, it follows from Lemma B. 2 that there exists at most one solution to each such system of scalar equations, and thereby also to the system of $T d^{2}$ linear equations (B.29), $t=1, \ldots, T$, in $M d^{2}$ variables. Since one solution is $\tilde{B}_{m}=B_{m}$ for all $m=1, \ldots, M$, this is the unique solution, concluding that the matrices $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{M}$ are uniquely identified almost everywhere in $\left[B_{1}: \cdots: B_{M}\right] \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times d M}$, given that the transition weights $\alpha_{m, t}, m=1, \ldots, M, t=1, \ldots, T$, are uniquely identified. For exogenous models, the identification of the transition weights is given. For logistic models, by Lemma 2, the transition weights weights are uniquely identified almost everywhere in $\left(y_{-p+1}, \ldots, y_{0}, y_{1}, \ldots, y_{T-1}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{d(T+p-1)}$ and, if $z_{t}$ is exogenous, $\left(z_{1}, \ldots, z_{T}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{T}$, concluding the proof.

# B. 5 Proof of Theorem A. 1 

Saikkonen (2008) establishes stationarity, ergodicity, and mixing properties of a STVEC model by making use of the theory of Markov chains. Kheifets and Saikkonen (2020), in turn, show that the results of Saikkonen (2008) are applicable to their STVAR model, as it can be obtained as a special case of the STVEC model of Saikkonen (2008). However, the results of Saikkonen (2008) and Kheifets and Saikkonen (2020) are not directly applicable to our structural STVAR model, because our model defines the conditional covariance matrix differently to the STVEC model of Saikkonen (2008) and STVAR model of Kheifets and Saikkonen (2020). Hence, certain steps need to be taken show the applicability of the results of Saikkonen (2008) to our structural STVAR model.

Note that by Assumption A.1(II), Assumption 1 in Saikkonen (2008) is satisfied. Moreover, by the constraint $\sum_{m=1}^{M} \alpha_{m, t}=1$, Assumption 2(a) in Saikkonen (2008) satisfied, and as we assume that

the set $1_{2}$ in Saikkonen (2008) is an empty set, also Assumption 2(b) is satisfied. Consequently, Condition (10) in Saikkonen (2008) is satisfied and by our Assumption A.1(I) also Condition (19). The difference of our setup to the conditions of Theorem 1 of Saikkonen (2008) is that our STVAR model specifies the conditional covariance matrix differently to the STVEC model defined in Equation (8) of Saikkonen (2008).

Besides the conditional covariance matrix, our structural STVAR model defined in Equations (3.2) and (3.3) is obtained from the stochastic process $z_{t}$ defined in Equation (17) (or equally (15)) of Saikkonen (2008) as follows ( $z_{t}$ of Saikkonen (2008) should not be confused with the switching variable of this paper). First, we assume that the number of unit roots in the model is zero, so $n=r$ in Saikkonen (2008). Consequently, $z_{t}=y_{t}$ and, in the definition of the matrix $J$ defined above Equation (17) of Saikkonen (2008), $\beta=c=I_{d}$ (see Saikkonen, 2008, Note 2). The matrix $J$ is thereby nonsingular, and following Kheifets and Saikkonen (2020), we can choose the matrix $S$ in Equation (17) to be the inverse of $J^{\prime}$. Second, we assume the transition functions $h_{s}\left(S^{\prime} J Z_{t-1}, \eta_{t}\right)$ of Saikkonen (2008) are independent of the random variable $\eta_{t}$. Hence, the transition functions are functions of $Z_{t-1}=\left(y_{t-1}, \ldots, y_{t-p}\right)$, and we can write $h_{s}\left(S^{\prime} J Z_{t-1}, \eta_{t}\right)=\alpha_{m, t}$. Using the notation of this paper, the first term on the right side of Equation (17) in Saikkonen (2008) then reduces to $\sum_{m=1}^{M} \alpha_{m, t} \sum_{i=1}^{p} A_{m, i} y_{t-i}$. Third, assume the set $1_{2}$ is empty, which implies that the second term on the right side of Equation (17), defined in Equation (11) of Saikkonen (2008), reduces to $\sum_{m=1}^{M} \alpha_{m, t} \phi_{m}$ (with the notation of this paper).

That is, the first two terms on the right side of Equation (17) in Saikkonen (2008), reduce to the first term on the right hand side of Equation (3.2) defining our structural STVAR model. The third term on the right side of Equation (17) in Saikkonen (2008), however, reduces to $\left(\sum_{m=1}^{M} \alpha_{m, t} \Omega_{m}\right)^{1 / 2} e_{t}$, where $\Omega_{1}, \ldots, \Omega_{M}$ are positive definite $(d \times d)$ covariance matrices of the regimes. This is different to the second term of Equation (3.2), which takes the form $\sum_{m=1}^{M} \alpha_{m, t} B_{m} e_{t}$ when the impact matrix (3.3) is substituted to it. Nonetheless, it turns out that with only slight modifications, the proof of Theorem 1 in Saikkonen (2008) applies to our model as well.

The conditional covariance matrix is relevant in only a few places in the proof of Theorem 1 in Saikkonen (2008). Firstly, on page 312, Saikkonen (2008) makes use of the positive definiteness of the conditional covariance matrix $H\left(S^{\prime} J Z_{t-1}\right)$ (or $\sum_{m=1}^{M} \alpha_{m, t} \Omega_{m}$ in our notation) to conclude that the smallest eigenvalue of $H\left(S^{\prime} J x\right), x \in \mathbb{R}^{d p}$, is bounded away from zero in compact subsets of $\mathbb{R}^{d p}$. Saikkonen (2008) argues that thereby by Theorem 2.2(ii) of Cline and Phu (1998), the Markov chain $Z_{t}$ is an irreducible and aperiodic T-chain on $\mathbb{R}^{d p}$, which is then used to conclude further results. Concerning our model, note that by Lemma 1, $B_{y, t}$ is invertible for all $t$ almost everywhere in $\left[B_{1}: \ldots: B_{M}\right] \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times d M}$, implying that the conditional covariance matrix $B_{y, t}\left(\boldsymbol{y}_{t-1}\right) B_{y, t}\left(\boldsymbol{y}_{t-1}\right)^{\prime}$ is positive definite, where the dependence of the conditional covariance matrix on the $(d p \times 1)$ random vector $\boldsymbol{y}_{t-1}=\left(y_{t-1}, \ldots, y_{t-p}\right)$ is made explicit in the notation. Hence, the smallest eigenvalue of $B_{y, t}(x) B_{y, t}(x)^{\prime}, x \in \mathbb{R}^{d p}$, is bounded away from zero in compact subsets of $\mathbb{R}^{d p}$. It follows from this, Equation (3.2), and the invertibility of $B_{y, t}$ that we can apply Theorem 2.2(ii) of Cline and Phu (1998) to conclude that the Markov chain $\boldsymbol{y}_{t}$ is an irreducible and aperiodic T-chain on $\mathbb{R}^{d p}$, similarly to the process $Z_{t-1}$ in Saikkonen (2008).

Secondly, the conditional covariance matrix appears in the proof of Saikkonen (2008) on page 313, where Saikkonen (2008) shows that an appropriate version of Condition (15.3) of Meyn and Tweedie (1993, p. 358) is satisfied. To show that this condition holds for our model, we need to show that an appropriate version of Equation (A.5) in Saikkonen (2008) holds for our model, i.e., that the term $E\left[\sup _{A \in \mathcal{A}^{j}}\left\|A B_{y, t}(x) e_{t}\right\|^{2}\right]$ is bounded from above by a finite real number, where $j$ is a positive integer, $\mathcal{A}=\left\{\boldsymbol{A}_{1}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{A}_{M}\right\}$, and $\boldsymbol{A}_{1}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{A}_{M}$ as well as the set $\mathcal{A}^{j}$ are defined in Appendix A.

Similarly to Saikkonen (2008, p. 313), clearly,

$$
\sup \left\{\|A\|: A \in \cup_{j=1}^{N} \mathcal{A}^{j}\right\}<c
$$

where $\|\cdot\|$ is Eucledian norm, $N$ is a positive integer, and $c$ a finite real number. Hence, because

$B_{y, t}(x)$ is a constant here, by Jensen's inequality and submultiplicativity of norms, we have

$$
E\left[\sup _{A \in \mathcal{A}^{j}}\left\|A B_{y, t}(x) e_{t}\right\|^{2}\right] \leq \sup _{A \in \mathcal{A}^{j}}\left\|A \|^{2}\left\|B_{y, t}(x)\right\|^{2} E\left[\left\|e_{t}\right\|\right]^{2}\right.
$$

where the right side is bounded from above by some finite constant (by (B.30) and the finite second moment of $e_{t}$ given by Assumption 1). Thus, an appropriate version of Equation (A.5) in Saikkonen (2008) holds for our model. Since the rest of the proof of Theorem 1 in Saikkonen (2008) thereby applies to our model as well, this concludes the proof.

# C Penalized nonlinear least squares estimation of STVAR models 

This appendix describes how the parameters of the structural STVAR model discussed in Section 3 can be estimated by the method of nonlinear least squares (NLS) as explained in Hubrich and Teräsvirta (2013, Section 4.2) for logistic STVAR models. After describing the NLS estimation, penalized nonlinear least squares (PNLS) estimation is considered by introducing a penalization term to the sum of squares of residuals function.

## C. 1 Nonlinear least squares estimation

Consider the following sum of squares of residuals function

$$
Q(\alpha)=\sum_{t=1}^{T} u_{t}(\alpha)^{t} u_{t}(\alpha)
$$

where $u_{t}(\alpha)=y_{t}-\sum_{m=1}^{M} \alpha_{m, t} \mu_{m, t}$ and the parameter $\alpha$ contains the weight function parameters. ${ }^{5}$ The NLS estimates of the parameters $\phi_{m}, A_{m, j}, j=1, \ldots, p$, corresponding to the weight function parameter $\alpha$ are obtained by minimizing $Q(\alpha)$ with respect to these parameters.

If the transition weights $\alpha_{1, t}, \ldots, \alpha_{M, t}$ are not exogenous, also the parameter $\alpha$ (they depend on) needs to be estimated. Since the NLS estimates of the AR parameters are analytically obtained for given $\alpha$, the optimization can be performed with respect to $\alpha$ only. However, this optimization problem is multimodal, and thereby standard gradient based optimization methods that are not able escape from local maxima are not sufficient. Since we only need approximate estimates to serve as starting values for Step 2 and 3 estimation in the three-step procedure described in Appendix 4.3, the following procedure is adopted.

First, determine the values of the transition weights $\alpha_{m, t}, m=1, \ldots, M, t=1, \ldots, T$, that can be deemed reasonable for estimation, i.e., transition weights that allocate a sufficient enough contribution to each regime in the model. As an extreme example, transition weights with $\alpha_{1, t}=0$ for all $t=1, \ldots, T$ are not reasonable, as Regime 1 would not be involved in the model at all. Thus, each regime should contribute to the model to an extend that is reasonable enough for estimation.

One way to assess the contribution of each regime is by summing over the transition weights, i.e., calculating the sums $\hat{\alpha}_{m} \equiv \sum_{t=1}^{T} \alpha_{m, t}, m=1, \ldots, M$. In the special case of discrete transition weights such as the threshold weights (2.3), the sums $\hat{\alpha}_{m}$ express the numbers of observations from each regime. Therefore, one way to determine whether a regime contributes enough to the model is to check whether the sums $\hat{\alpha}_{m}$ are large enough compared to the number of parameters in that regime for all $m=1, \ldots, M$. Denote the large enough sum as $\tilde{T}$. We assume that if there are $k$ parameters in a regime, and there should be at least three times as many observations from all the $d$ variables combined, implying $\tilde{T}=3 k d^{-1}$, then transition weights that satisfy $\hat{\alpha}_{m} \geq \tilde{T}$ for all $m=1, \ldots, M$ are deemed reasonable enough. ${ }^{6}$

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{5}$ With threshold weights (2.3), $\alpha=\left(r_{1}, \ldots, r_{M-1}\right)$, and with logistic weights (2.4) weights, $\alpha=(c, \gamma)$. If the transition weights are exogenous, we simply treat them as known constants.
    ${ }^{6}$ We acknowledge that our assumption of at least three times as many observations from all $d$ variables combined as there are parameters in a regime is somewhat arbitrary, but it attempts to deter obvious cases of overfitting, while still

Second, specify a range of reasonable parameter values for each scalar parameter in the $(s \times 1)$ vector $\alpha$, and specify a grid of parameter values within that range. For instance, for a logistic STVAR model, the location parameter should, at least, lie between the lowest and greatest value in the observed series of the switching variable, whereas the scale parameter can range from a small positive number some large positive number that implies almost discrete regime-switches. With $n$ grid points for each $s$ scalar parameters in $\alpha$, the number of different parameter vectors $\alpha$ with values in the grid points is $n^{s}$. Hence, we recommend selecting a sufficiently small number of grid points $n$, so that estimation can be performed in a reasonable computation time. Denote the $i$ th vector of $\alpha$ containing parameter values in the grid points as $\alpha^{(i)}, i=1, \ldots, n^{s}$. Then, obtain the subset of the grid points $\alpha^{(i)}$ that satisfy $\dot{\alpha}_{m} \geq \tilde{T}$ for all $m=1, \ldots, M$. Denote this subset as $\mathcal{W}$.

Finally, calculate the NLS estimates of the AR parameters for all $\alpha^{(i)} \in \mathcal{W}$, and the estimates yielding the smallest sum of squares of residuals $Q(\alpha)$ are the approximate NLS estimates of the parameters $\phi_{1}, \ldots, \phi_{M}, \varphi_{1}, \ldots, \varphi_{M}$, and $\alpha$. Notably, the NLS estimation does not necessarily produce estimates that satisfy the usual stability condition for all or any of the regimes.

# C. 2 Penalized nonlinear least squares estimation 

Penalized nonlinear least squares estimation of STVAR models works similarly to the NLS estimation, except that instead of the sum of squares function (C.1), the penalized sum of squares function is minimized. We define the penalized sum of squares function as

$$
P Q(\alpha)=Q(\alpha)-P(\alpha)
$$

where the penalization term $P(\alpha)$ increases as the parameter values approach the boundary of, or move further into, an uninteresting region of the parameter space. To focus on avoiding estimates allowing flexibility when the model is large compared to the number of observations.

that do not satisfy the usual stability condition for all regimes, we define the penalty term as

$$
P(\alpha)=\kappa \widehat{R S S} \sum_{m=1}^{M} \sum_{i=1}^{d p} \max \left\{0,\left|\rho\left(\boldsymbol{A}_{m}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right)_{i}\right|-(1-\eta)\right\}^{2}
$$

where

$$
\widehat{R S S}=\min _{\alpha \in \mathcal{W}} Q(\alpha)
$$

is the minimized residual sum of squares, $\left|\rho\left(\boldsymbol{A}_{m}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right)_{i}\right|$ is the modulus of the $i$ th eigenvalue of the companion form AR matrix of Regime $m$, the tuning parameter $\eta \in(0,1)$ determines how close to the boundary of the stability region the penalization starts, and $\kappa>0$ determines the strength of the penalization. Whenever the companion form AR matrix of a regime has eigenvalues greater than $1-\eta$ in modulus, the penalization term (4.4) is greater than zero, and it increases in the modulus of these eigenvalues. The penalty term (C.3) is multiplied by $\widehat{R S S}$ to standardize the strength of the penalization with respect to the fit of the model.

The penalized NLS estimates of $\phi_{m}, A_{m, j}, j=1, \ldots, p$, and $\alpha$, are obtained by first minimizing $Q(\alpha)$ for all $\alpha \in \mathcal{W}$, then calculating the penalty term $P(\alpha)$ for all $(\alpha) \in \mathcal{W}$, and finally selecting the estimates that give the smallest minimized the penalized sum of squares (C.2). In our empirical analysis in Section 5, we use the tuning parameter values $\eta=0.05$ and $\kappa=0.2$, in line with the tuning parameter values used in the PML estimation (see Section 4.2).

# D A Monte Carlo study 

This appendix present a Monte Carlo study that assesses the performance of the proposed penalized maximum likelihood estimator and the three-step estimation procedure discussed in Section 4 We consider simple bivariate (structural) TVAR and LSTVAR models with $p=1$ and $M=2$, two specifications of each, with the first lag of the first variable as the switching variable. To maintain some constancy, we use the same impact matrices across all specifications, $\operatorname{vec}\left(B_{1}\right)=$

![table_0](table_0)

Table D.1: The parameters values of $\phi_{1}, \phi_{2}, A_{1,1}$, and $A_{2,1}$ used for the models TVAR 1, TVAR 2, LSTVAR 2, and LSTVAR 2 in the Monte Carlo study. Also, the corresponding unconditional means of the regimes $\mu_{m}=\left(I_{d}-A_{m, 1}\right)^{-1} \phi_{m}, m=1,2$, and modulus of the eigenvalues of the companion form AR matrices of the regimes $\left\|\boldsymbol{A}_{m}\right\|, m=1,2$.
$(0.6,-0.3,0.2,0.4)$ and $\operatorname{vec}\left(B_{2}\right)=(0.7,0.1,0.3,0.8)$, as well as the same degrees-of-freedom and skewness parameter values, $\nu_{1}=2.5, \nu_{2}=12.0, \lambda_{1}=-0.5$, and $\lambda_{2}=0.2$. For TVAR models, we use the threshold parameter value $r_{1}=0.8$ and for LSTVAR models the location and scale parameter values $c=0.8$ and $\gamma=5.0$.

For both the TVAR model and the LSTVAR model, we consider two specifications of the AR matrices, presented in Table D.1. In the first specification (labelled as TVAR 1 and LSTVAR 1 for the TVAR and LSTVAR models, respectively), the AR matrices are well inside the stability region (see Section 4.1). In the second specification (labelled as TVAR 2 and LSTVAR 2 for the TVAR and LSTVAR models, respectively), the AR matrices are well inside the region where penalization term is strictly positive, allowing us to assess the performance of our estimation method when the true parameter value lies in the penalization region. To illustrate the closeness to the boundary, the modulus of the roots of the companion form AR matrix are presented in Table D. 1 (as in our empirical application, we use the tuning parameter values $\eta=0.05$ and $\kappa=0.2$ for the penalization term, so the penalization term is strictly positive when at least one the roots of the companion form AR matrix is larger than 0.95 in modulus). The intercept parameter values are adjusted so that the unconditional means of the regimes are approximately equal in both of the specifications (see Table D.1), so that the main difference between the specifications is that the second one includes true parameter values from inside the penalization region.

For each of the four model specifications, we generate 500 samples of length 250, 500, 1000, 2000, and 10000. Then, we fit the first-order two-regime TVAR model (for specifications TVAR 1 and 2)

or LSTVAR model (for specifications LSTVAR 1 and 2) to each of the generated sample using the three-step estimation procedure based on the penalized log-likelihood function, proposed in Section 4. After estimation, the ordering and signs of the columns of $B_{1}$ and $B_{2}$ are standardized by assuming, without loss of generality, that the degrees-of-freedom parameters are in an ascending order and that the first skewness parameter is positive and the second one negative, in line with the true parameter values. To estimate the bias of the PML estimator, we calculate the average estimation errors $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}-\boldsymbol{\theta}$ over the 500 Monte Carlo repetitions, and to estimate the spread of the estimates, we calculate their sample standard deviations.

The results of the Monte Carlo study are presented in Table D. 2 for the TVAR models and in Table D. 3 for the LSTVAR models. The results show that there is some but mostly very small bias, which diminishes when the sample size increases. Since also the standard deviation of the estimates diminishes with the sample size, our results are in line with consistency of the PML estimator. Nonetheless, for certain parameters, there appears to be a notable bias in small samples.

First, the estimator of the second degrees-of-freedom parameter (true parameter value $\nu_{2}=12$ ) is substantially biased upwards in samples of length $T=250,500$, and 1000 , and also the standard deviation of the estimates is very large. This can explained by the property of the skewed $t$ distribution that when the degrees-of-freedom parameter value is already large, increasing it more has virtually no effect on the shape of the distribution. Consequently, if a large degrees-of-freedom parameter fits the data, the numerical optimization algorithms are incapable of discriminating between large and very large parameter values. Hence, possibly very large degrees-of-freedom parameter values drawn by random in Step 2 estimation may remain large through Step 3 estimation. Since it is clear that there is virtually no difference in the economic interpretations of large (say, 100) and very large (say, 1000) degrees-of-freedom parameter values, the large upward bias should not be a concern.

Second, in the LSTVAR models, there is a substantial upward bias also for the scale parameter $\gamma$ when the sample size is small. A large scale parameter value indicates almost discrete regime-

switches, suggesting that the PML estimator is, in small samples, biased towards estimating too fast regime-switches when they are smooth in the true data generating process $(\gamma=5)$. The upward bias is possibly heightened by the property that when $\gamma$ is large, the regime-switches are already nearly discrete, making it difficult for numerical estimation algorithms to properly distinguish between large and very large values, particularly in small samples.

Third, the estimators of the first elements of the first rows of $B_{1}$ and of $B_{2}$ exhibit a notable upward bias when the sample is small. A possible explanation is that the bias is related to the heavy tails of the skewed $t$-distribution, as the true degrees-of-freedom parameter value is small $\left(\nu_{1}=2.5\right)$, and also, the estimators of the first elements of the second rows of $B_{1}$ and $B_{2}$ are biased more than the estimators of most of the other parameters. In particular, the estimates may be sensitive to extreme values drawn for the heavy-tailed skewed $t$ shocks, potentially amplifying small-sample bias.

In general, the small-sample bias of the PML estimator seems to be slightly larger the specifications where the true AR matrices are in the penalization region (TVAR 2 and LSTVAR 2) than the specifications where the true AR matrices lie well inside the stability region (TVAR 1 and LSTVAR 1). The differences are, however, only small, and even in small samples, there does not appear to be any particular issues with the estimation accuracy of the AR matrices lying inside the penalization region. Also, the TVAR models seem to be slightly more accurately estimated than the LSTVAR models, possibly because, unlike in TVAR models, in LSTVAR models also the smoothness of regime-switches needs to be estimated.

# E Details on the empirical application 

The estimation of the models, residual diagnostics, and computation of the GIRFs are carried out with the accompanying R package sstvars (Virolainen, 2025a) in which the introduced methods have been implemented. The R package sstvars also contains the dataset studied in the empirical application. In the below residual based model diagnostics, we have not labelled the residual series

by any of the variables, because labelling them effectively requires labelling the corresponding structural shocks, and only the CPU shock has been labelled.

To study whether our model adequately captures the autocorrelation structure of the data, we depict the sample autocorrelation functions (ACF) and cross-correlation functions (CCF) of the (nonstandardized) residuals for the first 24 lags in Figure E.1. There is not much autocorrelation left in the residuals, but there is a particularly large correlation coefficient (CC) in the lag zero CCFs between the fourth and fifth residual series. In addition, there are a few moderately sized CCs in the ACFs and CCFs of some of the residual series, but the vast majority of the CCs are small. Hence, with the exception of the single large CC in the lag zero CCFs of the fourth and fifth residual series, our LSTVAR model appears to capture the autocorrelation structure of the data reasonably well.

To study our model's adequacy to capture the conditional heteroscedasticity in the data, we depict the sample ACFs and CCFs of squared standardized residuals for the first 24 lags in Figure E.2. There is a very large CC in the lag zero CCFs between the second and third residual series, which, however, disappears if the COVID-19 residual from March 2020 is excluded (not shown). In addition, there are several sizeable CCs in the ACFs and CCFs of some of the residual series. Thus, there are some inadequacies in capturing the conditional heteroscedasticity, but with the exception of the large CC in CCFs between the second and third residual series (due to the extreme COVID-19 volatility), the inadequacies do not seem particularly severe.

Finally, the quantile-quantile-plots based on the independent skewed $t$-distributions with mean zero, variance one, and degrees-of-freedom as well as skewness parameter values given by their estimates are presented in Figure E. 3 for each residual series. They show that the marginal distributions of the series are reasonably well captured, although there is a single large outlier in the third residual series (which disappears if the March 2020 residual is removed; not shown). Therefore, the overall adequacy of the model seems, in our view, reasonable.

abstract:
Linear structural vector autoregressive models can be identified
statistically without imposing restrictions on the model if the shocks are
mutually independent and at most one of them is Gaussian. We show that this
result extends to structural threshold and smooth transition vector
autoregressive models incorporating a time-varying impact matrix defined as a
weighted sum of the impact matrices of the regimes. We also discuss the problem
of labelling the shocks, estimation of the parameters, and stationarity the
model. The introduced methods are implemented to the accompanying R package
sstvars. Our empirical application studies the effects of the climate policy
uncertainty shock on the U.S. macroeconomy. In a structural logistic smooth
transition vector autoregressive model with two regimes, we find that a
positive climate policy uncertainty shock decreases production and increases
inflation in times of both low and high economic policy uncertainty, but its
inflationary effects are stronger in the periods of high economic policy
uncertainty.
